chapters.title: Segment 6 (pages 42-53)
chapters.content:
30

2

Designing to win

Our first case study is of an outstanding designer who has had a

long and distinguished record as a highly successful and highly innovative designer in a highly competitive environment, that of Formula One racing car design.

Gordon Murray emigrated to Britain as a young, graduate engineer, from his home in South Africa where he had designed, built and raced his own car in club events. He joined the Brabham Formula One racing car team as a designer-draughtsman and was rapidly promoted to chief designer. For twelve years he carried the major responsibility for the design of a series of innovative and frequently successful racing cars. Brabham cars designed by Gordon Murray and driven by Nelson Piquet won two World Championships. In 1987 Gordon Murray then moved to the McLaren Formula One team as technical director. Through the four race seasons from 1988 to 1991, McLaren cars designed by Murray and his team won three World Championships with driver Ayrton Senna and a fourth with driver Alain Prost. In total, Gordon Murray’s cars won fifty-one Grands Prix races.

Gordon Murray then became technical director of McLaren Cars Limited, an off-shoot of the Formula One team, and became responsible for the design and development of a completely new, road-going ‘supercar’ – the McLaren F1, designed on the same rigorous principles as a Formula One car. As well as many technical innovations, the F1 featured a novel seating arrangement, with the driver positioned centrally and two passenger seats beside but slightly behind the driver, in an ‘arrowhead’ configuration (Figure 2.1).

32

DESIGN THINKING

FIGURE 2.1 (a) Gordon Murray’s sketch for the McLaren F1, showing the three-person seating arrangement with passengers slightly behind the central driver; (b) overhead view of the McLaren F1; (c) detail drawing side/ cutaway-view of the McLaren F1. Courtesy of Gordon Murray/McLaren Automotive.

DESIGNING TO WIN

After leaving McLaren, Gordon Murray established his own automotive design consultancy and has extended his career into a wide variety of vehicle forms, ranging from high-performance sports cars to small, efficient city cars, autonomous vehicles and a flat- packed truck for developing countries.

Background: Formula One designing

Formula One racing car design is significantly different from almost every other kind of design domain. Gordon Murray likens it to war. Engineering and technological development in wartime is the closest analogy to Formula One he can think of, with resources – human, financial and technical – being poured into the design and construction of machines that must have, and maintain, a vital performance edge over those of the opposition. Throughout the nine-month Formula One season there is a battle to be fought on a different field every other week, with a new campaign starting again every year.

This constant competitive atmosphere creates tremendous pressure, particularly on someone in the position that Gordon Murray was in for many years at Brabham of being totally in control of, and responsible for, the complete technical operation: designing, constructing, testing, racing and organizing, throughout the year, and from one year to the next. With the calendar of Grand Prix races fixed in advance, there is also constant time pressure, with no possibility of missing a race or practice session.

Throughout a Formula One racing season there is constant work to make continuous improvements and adjustments to the current car design. These may be responses to obvious shortcomings, such as component failures, or to assessments of the car’s performance and handling, either in general or in relation to certain features of certain race circuits. The performance improvements aimed for may seem incredibly tiny by other standards – perhaps one-tenth of a second per lap – but they can make the difference between winning or losing the race. And at the same time, every other team is also making constant improvements, so the situation is never static.

33

34

DESIGN THINKING

Radical innovation

Beyond continually making improvements during the season, there is a limit to what can be achieved with any car design before a jump has to be made to basically a new design. As Gordon Murray says, ‘Given the situation and the pressure at any one time, you do get to a brick wall. I mean, you’re doing all these normal modifications, you know you can’t go any quicker, you need to make the step forward.’ Typically, such a step forward happens during the short close-season, when every team seeks to start the coming new season with an advantage over its rivals.

In many instances, and for most teams, this will be a new version of the previous season’s car; perhaps a new chassis, new suspension or a new engine to be accommodated; perhaps a change in regulations to be met. For Gordon Murray it would often mean trying a ‘step forward’, a radical new concept. In the midst of the pressure, the fervour, the panic, he ‘used to get breakthroughs, I mean I used to get like suddenly a mental block’s lifted’. These breakthroughs would come as a sudden illumination: ‘I know it’s a cliché, but I really did have a lot of good ideas in the bath!’ But such illuminations came, again in classical form, after long periods of immersion in, and preoccupation with the problem.

In Formula One there are always strict design requirements to be met: the technical and sporting regulations, which minutely and precisely specify the physical and operational limits within which the teams must compete, and which can change from season to season. Gordon Murray regards the constraints (the regulations) of racing car design, along with its intense pressure and competition, as fundamental to the necessity to innovate. Outside of racing car design he thinks that there may not be enough pressure on the designer, nor tight enough regulations, nor strong enough competition, for such radical, innovative design thinking as in Formula One.

Another crucial factor is the necessity and the motivation to carry through the bright idea into detailed implementation. Again, intense pressure, even in the close-season, ensures that ideas that look certain to be winners will be pushed through to detailed implementation with the same fervour as in the racing season. Other possibly good

DESIGNING TO WIN

ideas are discarded on a rapid evaluation of their implications for a car’s weight, performance or handling. In Formula One design, it is a matter not just of having ideas but of really implementing ideas that are going to improve performance, of having to ‘do it’, as Gordon says, ‘You have the idea, but you have to do it, and that’s what cuts the bullshit out.’

Self-adjusting suspension

As one example of radical innovation, Gordon Murray refers to the development at Brabham of a novel suspension system. At the time, the then Formula One governing body, FISA, became concerned to reduce the designed-in ‘ground effect’ on the cars. This effect had been pioneered on the Lotus team’s cars; smooth underbodies lying very close to the ground, side skirts right down to the ground and careful aerodynamic design provided a low-pressure under-car area which increased the car’s grip on the track surface. This meant much higher cornering speeds were possible, to the extent that some people became worried about the heavy g-force effects that were being imposed on the drivers, which might cause them to loose consciousness. FISA decided to ban the ‘sliding’ skirts that kept the body-ground gap closed but allowed fixed skirts and set a minimum underbody ground clearance of 6 centimetres. For Gordon Murray this sudden change in regulations was a stimulus to innovation. His first World Championship-winning car, he said,

came absolutely from the regulation change. You sit there and you read the regulations and think, how we are going to do it? How the hell can we get ground-effect back? What [the regulations] said was ‘At all times the car will have a 6 centimetre gap between the bodywork and the ground . . . and there can be no driver-operated device to change that gap’. And everybody looked at it, and built cars with 6 centimetre gaps . . . and I looked at it and I thought, if that 6 centimetre gap could be a 1 centimetre gap I could double the ground effect on the car; and it’s going to go down to a 1 centimetre gap at some point, like [under braking] at the end of the straight. So if I can make a physical thing . . . that drives the car down on its own, and holds the car down on its own without

35

36

DESIGN THINKING

any mechanical aid or button or electrics or anything, it’s legal. So in three months we developed a hydro-pneumatic suspension system.

Gordon Murray’s thinking on this, and he says it came as a sudden illumination, was that the authorities had to accept that at some points during a race, any car’s ground clearance is going to be less than the 6 centimetres minimum simply because of the body dipping under braking, or rolling in corners and so on. Knowing that any driver- operated, mechanical device to alter the ground clearance was illegal, he focused on the physical forces, the ‘bits of nature’, that act on a car in motion. The downforce from air pressure on a moving car could, if the car was appropriately designed aerodynamically, push the car down over its whole length and width. The design challenge, therefore, was to let the natural downforce push the car down at speed, and then somehow to keep it down as it travelled around the circuit, but then allow the car to return to 6 centimetres clearance at standstill.

The ingenious solution used a hydro-pneumatic suspension system for the first time in Formula One, with struts at each wheel connected to hydraulic fluid reservoirs. As the car went faster, the natural downforce of airflow pushed the body lower on its suspension and the fluid in each suspension strut was pushed out into the reservoirs. The trick then was to find a way of letting the fluid return to the suspension struts only very slowly when the car slowed down. By the end of the first lap, the car body would be lower and would stay low, but on slowing down and stopping at the end of the race, the fluid would return from the reservoirs into the suspension struts, and the body would rise to the required 6 centimetres ground clearance.

Gordon Murray found how to achieve the required result in the

technology of micro-filters, used mainly in the medical industry.

They were using these organic micro-filters which let the fluid through themselves but very, very, very, slowly. And we built the world’s tiniest throttle valve with one of these filters in it, and a tiny little pin – we were using drills that you couldn’t even see! We went and quickly developed what size hole we needed, so that it took a

DESIGNING TO WIN

lap to push the fluid through these little holes – all naturally with the downforce – pushed the fluid into the reservoirs and the car was stuck on the ground, running with its skirts virtually touching the ground. And because it took so long for the fluid to get back through the same valves and filters, it held the car down there, and after the race you have the slowing down lap . . . and the car just slowly came back up. Nothing to do with the driver at all, just physical forces. And we went to the first race in Argentina and just blew everybody into the weeds, just totally; and everybody went bananas!

Other teams protested that the Brabham cars must have been fitted with a driver-operated device. It was obvious that the cars were lower during racing than they were in the pits, but of course the scrutineers could find no illegal device. Under pressure from the other teams, the authorities pointed out that the Brabham cars were clearly lower than 6 centimetres when out on the circuit, which contravened the regulations, but Gordon countered that, at various points, so was every other car. To curb the protests, he suggested to the authorities that every car could have its underbody painted, and at the end of the race every car which showed that at some point the underbody had rubbed the ground should be disqualified; and of course, the other teams would not accept this. Some other teams experimented haphazardly with variable suspension systems, but, very frustratingly for Gordon, just a few races later in the season, FISA reversed its stance and allowed driver-operated devices for controlling suspension height.

The Brabham self-adjusting suspension system was an example of an innovation initiated by a change in regulations which forced Gordon Murray’s thinking on how to retain the ground effect. It is an example of radical design innovation, through thinking from first principles about the effects of natural forces and having the motivation to follow through from a basic idea into finely detailed implementation.

Pit stops

Another example of radical innovation by Gordon Murray was the Brabham team’s introduction of planned pit stops for refuelling during

37

38

DESIGN THINKING

a race, before this became normal practice (and was eventually ruled out from the 2010 season, although still allowed for tyre changes). This was not so much an innovation in the car design per se but reflects more of a systems approach to the overall goal of winning each race. At that time it was not normal to have pit stops as regular, planned parts of the race routine and team strategy. Pit stops were for emergencies such as changing a punctured or badly worn tyre. For Gordon Murray, the innovation of introducing planned pit stops was part of an overall strategy arising from taking his thinking back to a basic issue – how to make the car lighter. The lighter the car, the faster it is in accelerating and decelerating.

Gordon says his mind was ‘banging away’ at this issue for a long time. He looked at the regulations and realized that there was nothing in them about when you could put fuel into the car. So the idea dawned of running the car with only a little over half the normal, full-race fuel load and including a pit stop for refuelling. But that was only the starting point for a thorough investigation of the implications of such an idea and of working through the detailed implementation. The first thing to do was to evaluate the implications of the idea. A pit stop took a lot of time; not only was there the actual stopped time of the car at the pits, but there was also the time lost in decelerating and driving into the pits and also in accelerating away again on tyres that take a couple of laps to heat up to optimum operating temperature. Formula One pit stops eventually became refined down to an incredibly quick norm of about six seconds actual stopped time, in which time over 100 litres of fuel were taken on and all four wheels changed. The total racing time lost was perhaps some twenty seconds. Gordon calculated that if the total racing time lost by a pit stop was less than twenty-six seconds, there could be sufficient advantage gained elsewhere to make it worthwhile.

There were many factors that came into calculating the advantage. As well as the weight reduction, half-size fuel tanks also have an advantage over full-size ones in that the car’s weight distribution is lower, and is more constant throughout the race, and the roll-couple on corners is lower, allowing faster cornering. The complicated choices of harder or softer tyre compounds also become a critical factor, because a lighter car can run on softer compounds which also improve cornering speeds. Even the psychology of racing came into

DESIGNING TO WIN

it, because a car with obvious advantages in the early part of a race could lead other competing drivers into pushing their cars harder, or into taking more risks. For all of the objective, measurable factors, fine calculations were made, leading to the conclusion that a pit stop had to lose less than twenty-six seconds of racing time to be worthwhile. At that time, a quick pit stop for tyre changes took about fifteen seconds of actual stopped time. Gordon Murray calculated that he had to get this down to about ten seconds and to reduce as much as possible the slowing-down and warming-up times. And so, ‘the innovation process continues, because you’ve got all these new things that nobody’s done before that you have to come up with’. An extraordinary development programme had to be undertaken in an incredibly short time.

From having the first idea to having a pit-stop car running and doing a test was three or four weeks, and that’s all the time that you have. So you would take each individual thing and tackle it. Say, OK, how can we get thirtyfive gallons into the car in ten seconds? The only way you’re ever going to do it is using pressure, and then you have a crash programme to develop a system . . . That’s what is great about race car design, because even though you’ve had the big idea – the ‘light bulb’ thing, which is fun – the real fun is actually taking these individual things, that nobody’s every done before, and in no time at all try and think of a way of designing them. And not only think of a way of doing them, but drawing the bits, having them made and testing them.

Within three weeks, they had thought of, designed, made and tested a pressure-fed refuelling system. To improve pit-stop procedures, Gordon hired a film crew to film the team practising pit stops and then played back the film, stopping it to identify difficulties and errors, and devising ways to improve the procedures. The new systems, the improvements and the training of the pit team got the actual stopped time down to under the target of ten seconds. One ‘big killer’ remained:

When you put new tyres on they were cold, and it always took two laps to get back up to speed, and the time you lost in those two

39

40

DESIGN THINKING

laps killed the whole thing. So then I thought, well I know the tyres start working at seventy degrees centigrade . . . so we designed an oven, a wooden oven with a gas-fired heater, and we heated the tyres up, and ten seconds before the car was coming in we opened the oven door, whipped the tyres out, put them on, and the guy was instantly quick. Now every Grand Prix team has tyre heating; that’s where it started.

Pit stops to change all four wheels and tyres with varying hard or soft compounds (with a stopped time of just a couple of seconds) are now a key factor in race strategy for every Formula One team.

The example of the introduction of the ‘pit-stop car’ illustrates how a radical innovation was driven by the competitive urge to find a significant advantage within the constraints of the regulations; how the basic creative idea had to be evaluated on precise calculations; how a total systems approach was adopted; and how implementation had to be carried through to fine levels of detail.

Designing from first principles

As well as the competitive pressure and the tight constraints, Gordon Murray emphasizes that an important factor in innovative design is reconsidering the problem situation from first principles; he stresses the need to ‘keep looking back at fundamental physical principles’. His innovative suspension system was based on such fundamental physical principles as the natural air-pressure downforce on a fast- moving car. The McLaren F1 sports car was also conceived according to the principles of Formula One design – principles such as lightness of materials, rigour of construction and optimization of performance. These principles were proved when some GTR racing versions of the F1 were produced; at their first outing, in the 1995 Le Mans twenty- four-hours race, McLaren F1s came first, third, fourth and fifth.

The unconventional ‘arrowhead’ seating layout (see Figure 2.1) also came from first principles. It is based on the racing principle of placing the driver at the centre of the car and is something he has used again in other car designs. It was something that Gordon Murray had had in mind for many years, as evidenced by a sketch for a car

DESIGNING TO WIN

design with the same layout in one of his student notebooks, some twenty-five years earlier. The seating layout is a very visible example of how he is prepared always to think anew about any aspect of the car that he is designing.

Steering column

As a less-visible example of his approach to designing from first principles, Gordon Murray refers to a small, and perhaps seemingly insignificant, part of the McLaren F1, the steering column. ‘Conventionally, it would have been, right, steering columns are typically three-quarter-inch solid steel bars.’ He explained how this conventional solution arises because the column not only has to carry torsional forces from the resistance to the turning wheels but also bending loads from the driver leaning and pulling on it whilst getting in and out of the car. It also has conventional points of support, is mounted in rubber bushes to reduce noise and is encased in a plastic housing for reasons of appearance and convenience. But it does not provide the sort of direct steering feel that a racing driver needs and that feeling was supposed to be one of the principles embodied in the design of the McLaren F1.

So Gordon decided to start by separating the needs to carry both torque and bending loads. Whatever the form of the steering column itself, it still needs a cover to house electrical cables and to mount switches, ‘so if you’ve got to have that anyway, why not use the insect principle where the skeleton’s on the outside, and make that the structure that takes all the bending forces?’ This thinking led to the design of the steering column itself as an aluminium tube of just 1 millimetre wall thickness, possible because it is only taking torque and not tension or compression. The support point is closer behind the steering wheel rather than down at the dashboard, and the system is now much lighter but stronger than a conventional solution and also has the right racing feel (Figure 2.2). The design process stemmed from considering first principles – separating the torque and bending loads – and from an imaginative breakthrough – using the housing cover for structural purposes as well as appearance and practicality.

41

42

DESIGN THINKING

FIGURE 2.2 Gordon Murray’s explanatory sketch of the F1 steering column design. Top: the F1, with an ‘exo-skele- ton’ structural external casing to house cables and hold switches, and a rigidly mounted small, light steering column; Bottom: a conventional design, with a heavy, solid column inside a light casing. Courtesy of Gordon Murray.

Gordon Murray insists on keeping experience ‘at the back of your mind, not the front’ and to work from first principles when designing. For instance, in designing a standard component such as a suspension wishbone, he says, ‘It’s all too easy, and the longer you’re in design the easier it is to say, I know all about wishbones, this is how it’s going to look because that’s what wishbones look like.’ But if you want to take a step forward, if you’re looking for ways of making it much better and much lighter, then you have to go right back to first principles. He says it is like always designing things as though for the first time, rather than the n-th time.

Case note: Analogical thinking

In his design of the McLaren F1 steering column, Gordon Murray

used an analogy with the exoskeleton structure that some insects have. The use of analogical thinking is common in designing, with biological analogies often being used to inspire creative thinking

DESIGNING TO WIN

(something like Philippe Starck’s analogical inspiration of the form of a squid for his lemon squeezer) or translated into technical applications.

Analogical thinking in design has been studied quite extensively. For example, Martin Stacey and his colleagues looked at idea creation by analogical transfer in a study of a team of designers who were generating ideas for a new product: a ‘digital pen’ using novel print-head technology. The envisaged pen might be a children’s toy or perhaps a craft or art tool. Some initial issues that were identified from an existing basic engineering prototype included keeping the print-head level and constraining the way it contacts potential printing media.

Here is an extract of the team’s discussion of ideas on how to

control the print head and keep it flat on a variable surface:

Jack: A sledge manages to keep level by having quite a wide base and then a main force in the middle, unlike a set of skis which are quite narrow and you go up on an edge when you’re turning. A sledge is quite broad and you have the weight right in the middle so they manage to keep both runners on the snow.

Alan: So would you potentially see some guiders down the side

of it?

Jack: Well, I guess the easiest way to keep the pen at a right angle would be to have a set of stabilizers on it, like a bicycle. Chad: I was thinking of maybe like a flat base with a sort of universal joint like a windsurf mast. The face is quite big but it stays flat, but the bit you hold on to can be at different angles.

The analogies brought into play here are far removed from the immediate context of the design project, going from a sledge to children’s bicycle stabilizers to a windsurf mast. In this example they are all to do with controlling and guiding a flat object moving across a variable and low-friction surface. At other times, closer analogies might be used – at one point the team was discussing the unusually broad head of this pen:

Chad: So it’s more like a paintbrush isn’t it, like a DIY paintbrush Tom: It’s more like a roller, yeah

43

44

DESIGN THINKING

Analogies are used in design thinking not only as inspiration for a specific solution idea but also as concise ways to suggest an underlying principle that might then lead to a range of solution ideas. As well as solution generation they are also used in problem identification and formulation and to explain or elaborate in communicating a concept.

Source: Martin Stacey, et al.: From Ronchamp by Sledge, in About Designing.

Integrated design

Gordon Murray is known principally as a racing car designer. But for many years he nursed a very different concept of what a car could be: a small, cheap, efficient city car. After he left McLaren he began development of this very different kind of car in his own design company. The resulting concept was announced as the T.25 city car. The T.25 is a very practical urban-use vehicle that can carry a driver with two passengers or with a large amount of luggage or shopping; it is light and agile, with good performance and low fuel consumption, and occupies one-third of the road or parking space of a conventional car.

For this car Gordon Murray also developed an innovative manufacturing process, which is as important to the project as the innovative automotive design concept. This integrated thinking was essential to his approach to designing a low-cost solution, as he explained:

You need something that is small, light, radical, efficient, and it has to be cheap, because one thing you can’t do is build the world’s most sophisticated little city car that will save the world and then say to people it costs £20,000, because you won’t sell many – if you don’t sell enough it won’t make a difference, and the way you reduce the cost of producing a car and therefore the retail price is by first of all reducing the part count, the number of parts that go into the car, and that you do by design and by conceptual design.

DESIGNING TO WIN

So for Gordon Murray conceptual design, detail design and manufa- cturing are all tightly bound together.

City car

Gordon Murray’s motivation for designing the T.25 city car was not just the economic and environmental advantages it might offer but also a desire to design an efficient, small car that would be attractive and fun to drive and would radically impact traffic problems such as congestion. His aim was to develop not just a new type of car but a new concept of personal transport.

Just as in his racing car design work, the city car is also designed from first principles. This is clear in some of Gordon’s earliest sketches for the car, in which he pays special attention to the suspension system (Figure 2.3). The suspension system is an important feature in early considerations because a tall, narrow car such as the T.25 tends to roll sideways on corners and that has to be countered in the suspension system. He also explained that, for economy, ‘I want to

FIGURE 2.3 Some of Gordon Murray’s early sketches for the city car concept: (a) overall concept, (b) a very early sketch of suspension and other details, made in a pocket notebook, around the same time as the concept sketches. Courtesy of Gordon Murray.

45

46

DESIGN THINKING

make a suspension with the least number of components and moving parts; this has only three parts in the whole suspension system’. The same kind of thinking applied also, for example, to the ‘frog-eye’ style of headlight design.

It’s not just styling, it’s a practical point of view because I only want to have one sub-wiring loop for cost, so I want to put the [wing] mirror in the back of the light, so you have headlamp, parking lamp, main beam, low beam, indicators, side repeater, heating element, adjusting element for the mirror, and the mirror, on one sub-loop with one plastic plug, so you have one moulded pod that does all those things, all those functions.

Even a radical concept such as the easy access, lift-up opening canopy, rather than side doors, came from the same approach.

Going from seven openings to five makes a car a lot cheaper and more rigid and lighter; going from five to three and from three to two is magic, and going down to one you can’t get any better – you’ve got to get into the car. So that sort of stuff you think about from the beginning, and that applies to lights, mirrors, instruments, wheels, brakes, everything.

After producing many dozens of small sketches of details and concepts over several years (Figure 2.4), and experimenting with performance, using different engines in some existing small cars, the design work took a major step forward when Gordon and his team built a very simple, full-size mock-up of the car, using wire and cardboard (Figure 2.5). The final version of the city car (Figure 2.6) bore a striking resemblance to that simple mock-up. The mock-up was also a useful design tool, as it began to suggest some new possibilities. For example, Gordon’s earlier idea for the seating arrangement was for two people sitting in tandem, the passenger behind the driver. But when the mock-up was built, ‘we discovered that you could, quite easily with the same width of motor car, for short journeys, you could take three people in it’, using a similar seating layout as in the McLaren F1. Another cost-saving idea also arose from exploring

DESIGNING TO WIN

FIGURE 2.4 Later sketches by Gordon Murray for the T.25 city car. Courtesy of Gordon Murray.

the mock-up, when one of the team realized that the rear-located engine could be accessed from inside the car, so avoiding the need for external access. Gordon explained:

At one stage, we were looking at having to have a boot lid to access the engine, until one of the guys said, Come and look at this, if you stand in the car you can open what is effectively your boot floor from the inside of the car, you can get to the oil and water and stuff from there – you fold up the seats, open the hatch in the floor and you are there.

The T.25 had a 660 cc petrol engine, but a T.27 electric version was developed as well. Like Gordon Murray’s Formula One cars and the McLaren F1, both the T.25 and T.27 were also winners – but for energy economy rather than speed. In 2010 the T.25 won the Royal Automobile Club’s Future Car Challenge, with a 97 miles per gallon fuel consumption over the 60-mile course from Brighton to London, and the next year the T.27 won the electric car class and best overall, with an energy consumption of just 7 kilowatt-hours, equivalent to 340 miles per gallon. In the city car design we can see

47

48

DESIGN THINKING

FIGURE 2.5 The early wire and card mock-up for the city car, showing the single opening canopy. Courtesy of Gordon Murray. Photograph by Nigel Cross.

that Gordon Murray applied the same kind of design thinking as in his racing car designs. There is a breadth of approach towards an overall, high-level goal, complemented by close attention applied across all levels right down to fine details, and all interlocking into the overall concept.

DESIGNING TO WIN

FIGURE 2.6 The first prototype version of the T.25 city car. Courtesy of Gordon Murray Design.

Case note: Modelling

Simple models and mock-ups such as the wire and cardboard

model of Gordon Murray’s city car are often used in exploring solution ideas. For example, in early development of a new model of vacuum cleaner within the Dyson company, the team built a simple cardboard model that attempted to combine the best ideas that had emerged from earlier individual activity and group discussions (Figure 2.7). The model is largely made from corrugated cardboard, with a thin sheet of clear plastic bent around to give an impression of the transparent dust-cyclone casing. It represents some almost- fixed decisions about how big the motor might be and how big the dust collection cylinder might be. It helps in answering questions such as: are the wheels the right size, how is access to the filter arranged, where will the cable retract to? It also facilitates and enhances communication within the team, which can begin to debate subtle changes to configurations and identify strengths and weaknesses.

49

chapters.title: Segment 8 (pages 62-69)
chapters.content:
50

DESIGN THINKING

There is a deliberate roughness and incompleteness in the model. Allowing parts of the design to be vague or unresolved has advantages: it allows the maker and the viewers to focus their attention on those elements that are under discussion or are more or less resolved, and by only vaguely modelling components the designer can build in some ambiguity. Team members might view this ambiguity in many different and positive ways, resulting in a number of interpretations and ideas from the model.

As David Mlynski, the design engineer who built the model said, ‘When I’m modelling in card I’m still exploring the problem. It’s part of my creativity. Sometimes I can draw my ideas and I use this to clarify my own thinking and to share ideas with others. But at other times I’m thinking and making at the same time. I couldn’t ask someone to make the model for me because I’m designing it as I’m making it.’

FIGURE 2.7 The Dyson DC05 vacuum cleaner. (a) An early development model, (b) the production version. Courtesy of Dyson.

Source: Steve Garner: Case Studies of Design and Designing.

Learning from failure

For Gordon Murray, it is the pressure of competitive design and the necessity to follow through ideas into rigorous implementation that results in successful innovation. He suspects that many people have bright ideas, but that they lack the experience and the motivation to

DESIGNING TO WIN

carry them through to fruition: ‘They have this great idea and then they lose interest.’

However, he also admits that not all his racing car design innovations have been successes; he has had a share of failures, too, and is willing to learn from the experience. One of his significant failures was the Brabham ‘surface cooling’ car. This radical concept was meant to be several steps forward at once: reduction in weight, improvement in driver safety and what was meant to be a long-term technical advantage over the opposition. His imaginative idea of surface cooling was to do away with normal radiators for cooling the engine, and instead to pass the water and oil through surface heat exchangers built integrally into the monocoque structure; the ‘skin’ of the car was therefore both structure and radiator.

There were innumerable detailed implementation problems with the surface cooling features, and trials soon showed that surface cooling was not going to work. So a revamped version of the previous season’s car had to be rushed out for the new season. However, Gordon was also working on another radical innovation, related not only to cooling the engine but also to increasing the car’s ground effect. Introduced in the middle of the season, this new version became known as the ‘fan car’ because it was fitted at the rear with a large fan, primarily for cooling the engine but which also happened to extract large amounts of air from underneath the car and therefore enhance the downforce. Driven by Niki Lauda, the car easily won its first race, but, as with the attempt to increase ground effect with the hydro-pneumatic suspension system, it faced immediate protests from the other teams. The use of the fan was controversial because although engine cooling fans were legal, devices for increasing downforce were not. Gordon’s argument was that ‘If we don’t have the fan then the engine will overheat’. However, the protests were so strong and influential that the Brabham team decided not to use the fan car again after its first race. It wasn’t exactly a failure, but Gordon learned from the experience of the fan car, and much later, in 2020, introduced a more sophisticated version of the concept in the design of his new sports car, the Gordon Murray Automotive T.50 (Figure 2.8). This supercar is claimed to have the most advanced aerodynamics of any road car, offering an ultra-smooth body shape and marking a new development in ground-effect innovations

51

52

DESIGN THINKING

FIGURE 2.8 The Brabham BT46B Formula One ‘fan car’ of 1978 (above) and (below) the Gordon Murray Automotive T.50 supercar of 2020 which also uses a rear-mounted fan to control underbody airflow. Courtesy of Gordon Murray Automotive.

through active management of the underbody airflow, controlled by its rear-mounted fan – the same feature that had been introduced years before in the ‘fan car’.

Another innovative design that failed was the last one Gordon Murray designed for Brabham, before he moved to McLaren. This car was designed to be as low as possible, with the driver almost lying flat. It involved also putting the engine into a reclined position, and this was the feature that proved not to work. Gordon said, ‘We just could not get the lay-down engine to scavenge the oil properly, and we kept losing a lot of horsepower.’ But he learned from the failure, and two years later at McLaren he was able to develop the same concept more successfully:

I did a lay-down McLaren, just like at Brabham but with a Honda engine that worked, and we won fifteen out of the sixteen races. So you do have things that don’t work; but in that case it wasn’t the idea that didn’t work, I just ran out of time and money, and I took on much too much in a very short period to get it to work properly.

Despite having experienced some failures and disappointments, Gordon Murray learns from failures and retains a commitment to holding on to good ideas, and re-purposing them when an opportunity arises.

DESIGNING TO WIN

Design process and working methods

Although Gordon Murray carried immense personal responsibility for the design work of his racing cars, and of course for his city car, for which he founded his own company, inevitably it involved a lot of teamwork. Clearly he has been successful in inspiring others to work with him. He likes to involve team members in the design problems and for that reason prefers to recruit all-rounders to his team: ‘I never have engineers that aren’t designers.’ He also likes to work collectively, standing around a drawing board or a mock-up discussing problems and trying ideas. For the McLaren F1 design, he installed a five-metre long drawing board in the design office, so that the car could be drawn full size, and several team members could gather round to contribute. He likes to have people around ‘to bounce ideas off’, and prefers to give them enough freedom and responsibility to feel that they are really making a worthwhile contribution to the team. His personal motivation manifests itself in a dedication which he also expects to find in the other members of his design team; he expects to appoint people who ‘if you cut them, they bleed motor oil’.

Gordon’s personal design process is based on starting with a quick sketch of a whole idea, which is then developed through many different refinements. He said that,

I do a quick sketch of the whole idea, and then if there’s one bit that looks good, instead of rubbing other bits out, I’d put that bit to one side; I’d do it again and expand on the good bit, and drop out the bad bit, and keep doing it, doing it; and end up with all these sketches, and eventually you end up throwing ninety percent of these away.

He also talks to himself – or rather, writes notes to himself on the sketches, notes such as ‘rubbish’, ‘too heavy’ or ‘move it this way 30 mm’. Eventually he gets to the stage of more formal, orthographic drawings, but still drawing annotated plans, elevations and sections all together, ‘Until at the end of the day the guys at Brabham used to call them “Gordon’s Wonder Plots”, because they used to say “It’s a wonder anybody could see what’s in them”!’

53

54

3

Designing to please

This second case study is based on interviews with another

outstanding designer, the industrial designer, Kenneth Grange. As with the previous chapter, the main purpose of making this study is to seek insight into the design thinking of someone who is a very successful, innovative designer.

Kenneth Grange is a well-known and very experienced designer of a great variety of products that range in scale from ball-point pens and shavers to taxi cabs and railway engines. His career has spanned over more than fifty years, and many of his designs became (and remain) familiar items in the household or on the street – or on the rail track. These designs include food mixers for Kenwood, razors for Wilkinson Sword, cameras for Kodak, typewriters for Imperial, clothes irons for Morphy Richards, washing machines for Bendix, pens for Parker, lamps for Anglepoise and the front end of the British Rail high-speed train engine. He is one of the RSA’s elite corps of ‘Royal Designers for Industry’, and his designs have won ten UK Design Council Awards and the Duke of Edinburgh’s Prize for Elegant Design. He has won the Gold Medal of the Chartered Society of Designers, and in 2001 he was awarded the Prince Philip Designers’ Prize – an award honouring lifetime achievement.

Background: The art of technical design

Kenneth Grange’s very successful career appears to have started and developed initially by a series of accidents. The son of a policeman, the

56

DESIGN THINKING

fourteen-year-old Kenneth ‘volunteered’ at school for the opportunity to apply for a scholarship to art school. After four years at Willesden School of Arts and Crafts, London, where ‘all I really learned was draughtsmanship’, and a short job as a scene painter with the BBC’s television department, the principal of the art school recommended Kenneth to ‘go and see a woman he knew who was working in the Institute of Town Planning’. This contact in turn recommended him to some architect friends of hers, who turned out to be the firm of Arcon, a leading progressive architectural firm of that era. Kenneth recalls that ‘I had never heard of architecture, I hadn’t the slightest idea of what this meant, but they gave me a job in what they called their technical publications department’, making presentation drawings for clients.

Soon after, at age nineteen, Kenneth Grange was then subject to two years of conscription into the British Army, where his ‘little portfolio’ of drawings got him allocated not to painting camouflage on tanks as he might have expected but as an illustrator producing drawings for instruction manuals. This work involved taking apart, usually by personal trial and error, various artillery mechanisms and then making drawings to illustrate the parts and their assembly. ‘You had to draw them in such a way, order the drawings in such a way, that it was a re-assembly process that you were explaining.’ This self-instruction in the assembly and re-assembly of military machines became Kenneth’s introduction to technical design, and the beginning of his fascination with the way things work, with the necessities of practicality and function that became underlying principles of his approach to design.

After leaving the Army, Kenneth returned to his architect colleagues for work. One of the Arcon partners, Jack Howe, encouraged Kenneth to undertake some independent work of his own. These private jobs were mostly ‘week-ends painting a mural or whatever. But somehow I picked up a little job which was doing an exhibition for the then [UK] Atomic Energy Authority’. This little job was so successful that the client called him again some months later, to say ‘We’ve taken space at an exhibition in Geneva, and would you like to design the exhibition stand for us?’ The new job turned out to be too large for Kenneth to be able to cope with on his own, ‘but within a month I’d got three people working for me full-time, and we were working in my flat, we’d taken over the living-room as well as the little office-workshop I’d got, and with every week the job increased. It turned into a big, big

DESIGNING TO PLEASE

job’. And so the Kenneth Grange design consultancy was accidentally up and running.

Looking for improvement

A significant feature of much of Kenneth Grange’s design work is that it often arises from a fundamental reassessment of the purpose, function and use of the product. However, this radical, innovative ability is not necessarily the reason why clients invite him to take on a new job. He says: ‘You are invariably brought in by somebody who has got a very elementary commercial motive in changing the perception of the product. It’s extremely unusual for someone to be brought in to approach it from this usability, this function theme.’ But he feels the need for a ‘secure foundation’ when starting a new project and that foundation is the product functionality: how things work and how they are used.

I am never daunted by the blank sheet of paper because I know I can at least fill in my time by trying to sort out just the functionality, just the handling of it, and by-and-large out of that comes a direction, and then it’s a question of tuning. I think it’s due to what your temperament is, your personality. I think, with my background, and my own knowledge about my weaknesses, I am bound to need to have a secure foundation on which I stand when I am arguing about something, and I am not very comfortable when I find myself required to be the prima donna.

His practical attitude towards product functionality also extends into his normal, everyday life. ‘As I get older I get less and less tolerant of things that don’t work easily, and so I think I go around looking for trouble!’ As an example, he recounts an experience in a restaurant, specializing in serving mussels:

The waiter comes along and dumps on the table a big stainless steel bowl [of mussels] with a lid, and this is hot. My companion’s lid had handles on it, and mine didn’t have handles on it. That made me furious, and I alone in that restaurant – probably they have never had anybody else complain about it – but not Grange: he

57

chapters.title: Segment 9 (pages 70-77)
chapters.content:
58

DESIGN THINKING

shouts and hollers and tells the waiter and calls for the manager. I can’t resist it, because I find that so much like a real affront!

Sewing machine

Being affronted by the poor usability of a product means that in his own design work Kenneth Grange inevitably puts ease of use at the forefront of his thinking. A clear example of this is provided by his design of a sewing machine for Frister & Rossman, a firm based in Germany producing high-quality, well-engineered machines, who were looking for new designs to update their product range. In this case, Kenneth’s attitude led him into trying out the existing sewing machine and looking for ways in which to improve it from the user’s point of view. From those insights he was able to generate a completely new version of a standard product. His resulting design incorporated the existing machinery but repackaged it in novel ways that made the machine easier to use and gave it a new and distinctive form and style (Figure 3.1).

The origins of the new design features lay in Kenneth’s functional, practical approach and on his personal experience. His starting point was his own use of the sewing machine: ‘I chose to use it, actually making things with a sewing machine, so I did fairly quickly come to understand just fundamental strengths and weaknesses.’ He found what he regarded as a ‘contradiction’ in the conventional design. The sewing machine mechanism is conventionally located centrally over its base platform, whereas the user needs more surface space on their side in front of the needle, rather than behind it. He explained that, ‘In front of the needle, the deeper the table on which you can actually assemble and lay and just get the tension of the fabrics right, the better. Once the work is behind the needle you can do nothing about it, it’s sewn, therefore you don’t need any more space for the fabric.’ Kenneth therefore simply moved the sewing machine mechanism rearwards on its base, creating an off-centre layout with more base-table space in front of the needle than behind it. To him, this appeared a virtually self- evident improvement to make: ‘This is such a straightforward thing to do, but the reason it had not been done before was because the sewing machine had been designed as a very straightforward, basic piece of engineering which needed stability. Therefore the mechanism

DESIGNING TO PLEASE

FIGURE 3.1 The Frister & Rossman sewing machine designed by Kenneth Grange. Courtesy of Kenneth Grange.

was from the very beginning put centrally upon the base and nobody had thought about challenging the space beyond and the space in front of the needle.’ Once this challenge had been met, and the benefit of an off-centre layout perceived, then ‘the rest of the shape follows, the rest of the shape just absolutely falls into place from that’.

Another radical change in this particular sewing machine design was also a result of a simple, fundamental assessment of how the machine is used. Kenneth gave the base of the machine rounded lower edges, which might look like a mere ‘styling’ feature, but in fact also arose from function.

There was something that they told me, which is that a frequent problem with sewing machines, particularly when you are sewing a new fabric, is that a lot of lint comes off the fabric, loose fibres and so on. This gets down into the bobbin and at worst stops the machine, at best will get itself sewn back into the thing, so you haven’t got an absolutely clean stitch, which affects the tension, the thread, etc. And they said, this is a problem, and their way of dealing with it was to make sure you could open the front and get the bobbin out.

59

60

DESIGN THINKING

This was achieved by the user tilting the machine away from them into a rather unstable position that only allowed restricted access to the shuttle mechanism in the underside of the base.

To Kenneth Grange, this was simply inadequate. ‘I thought, that doesn’t seem to me to be very clever, why don’t we make sure we can open the thing and really get at it? So I tilted the thing sideways, I rolled the whole thing back so it stood up and was very firm, and you could get the whole of the guts apart and get at the lint and so on, and that in itself generated a shape because then the back edge of the machine naturally had a roll to it.’ The rounded edge made it easier for the user to tilt the machine, it rested more stable and secure, and the underside was accessible for cleaning and oiling the lower mechanisms. A rounded top front edge was also provided to the base plate, to allow the fabric to slide over it more easily, and various other features were added, such as small drawers for holding accessories. Kenneth’s sketches, illustrating his approach, are shown in Figure 3.2. The sewing machine design demonstrates how Kenneth Grange approaches design from a functional viewpoint. The innovative ‘style’ and features of the new machine were generated from considering and responding to the normal patterns of its use. He says, ‘I think it’s a question of what your attitude is towards anything, any working thing. My attitude is to want it to be a pleasure to operate. I’m a great believer in pleasure in products.’ But it is not only the product’s user he seeks to please, it’s also important to please the client who commissioned it: it’s about ‘wanting to please the consumer and the client’.

Another aspect of this approach is that he considers the whole pattern of use, as exemplified by considering the requirements for periodically cleaning the machine, and by considering how the user prepares and introduces the fabric into the stitching mechanism, thus requiring more make-up space in front of the needle than behind it. It is a fundamental part of his interest in how things work: ‘Those are the things that intrigue me, recognising that there is a difference between what happens after a particular process and what happens before it, and so on, and preparing yourself for those two stages.’

The case of redesigning the sewing machine is an example of Kenneth Grange’s attitude of frustration with poor design, as evidenced in his account of the handle-less mussels pot. Like most designers, he has an attitude of discontent towards many existing products: they can always be improved. He says, ‘The designer should be inquisitive

DESIGNING TO PLEASE

FIGURE 3.2 Kenneth Grange’s sketches summarizing some of the principles underlying his design of the sewing machine. Courtesy of Kenneth Grange.

and incurably unsatisfied, because the majority of things around us do not work as well as they should.’ This designerly form of constructive discontent arises from having a critical attitude of looking at products to spot weaknesses in their designs, and not just criticizing them but finding ways of improving them through constructive design thinking.

Case note: Constructive thinking

Kenneth Grange’s designerly attitude of constructive

discontent derives from noticing that many products are poorly designed: the designer has an appreciation that things could be designed better. This constructive thinking is often triggered by observing how things are actually used by people and noticing the difficulties, large or small, that they experience but perhaps take for granted.

61

62

DESIGN THINKING

Industrial designer Sam Farber noticed that, because of the arthritis in her hands, his wife was experiencing difficulty and discomfort whilst using a vegetable peeler. Conventional vegetable peelers were ugly as well as difficult and uncomfortable to use. Sam might have taken over the peeling himself but, as a designer, he realized there was a need to develop new kitchen utensils for the many people who had difficulty handling conventional kitchen utensils, and that they could be more effective and aesthetically pleasing. Sam’s idea was for a new peeler that would be comfortable and secure to grip and manipulate when both dry and wet, attractive and moreover an inclusive design usable by a broad range of users.

Sam worked on this concept with the Smart Design consultancy. They developed a design for the peeler based on an oval handle form with soft, flexible fins carved into it to provide the required improved grip for finger and thumb (Figure 3.3). They used a neoprene material that is squeezable and has a comfortable, soft feel with a slight friction to help the grip. The design for the vegetable peeler was the start of a whole new range of kitchen products produced by OXO, a company that Farber started. The products have won awards for usability, appearance and innovative use of materials. Sam has been quoted: ‘It’s hard to think of a vegetable peeler as a radical innovation. But I guess it was!’

FIGURE 3.3 (a) The OXO GoodGrips vegetable peeler; (b) typical pre-OXO peelers. Courtesy of OXO. Photographs by Nigel Cross.

Source: Jonathan Cagan and Craig Vogel: Creating Breakthrough Products.

DESIGNING TO PLEASE

Going beyond the brief

Kenneth Grange was initially very unsure about presenting his sewing machine design proposal to his clients. These were actually the directors of the company that owned Frister & Rossman, the Maruzen company, based in Osaka, Japan. After being carefully briefed by them in Osaka, he returned to England to start the design work and actually developed two different designs. One was the radical new design and the other was more conservative – ‘It created a new form, but followed the brief precisely and did not alter the basic layout of the mechanics.’ Kenneth returned to Osaka with models of both designs.

The night before I was due to present my proposal, I looked long and hard at the two versions. I was afraid of looking foolish should some blindingly obvious reason be revealed for not deviating from the original brief. Only when I left my room the following morning did I decide to opt for excitement and take them the non-briefed model. In the event, they were very impressed.

Going well beyond the requirements of the original brief was also a major feature of one of Kenneth Grange’s most prestigious and long- lasting designs, the front bodywork of the high-speed train introduced into passenger service by British Rail in the 1970s, and still in use. It was perhaps surprising for an industrial designer, usually working on much smaller machines and devices, to find himself involved in the design of such a major engineering work, but again it illustrates Kenneth’s functional approach, eagerness to make improvements and to do what seems necessary, rather than just what is asked for.

Kenneth recalls that ‘They didn’t call me up and say, We’d like you to design a locomotive’. It began much more modestly, as a result of some smaller jobs that he had undertaken for the railway company, such as redesigning their timetables.

I had done a number of jobs for the railways, all quite modest jobs, but one or two of them quite important; like I was responsible for changing the basic format of timetabling. When I was asked to redesign a timetable for them, it was one of those printed sheets

63

64

DESIGN THINKING

that you got, organised from purely the point of view of the driver, which is the way the railways grew up. They were actually drivers’ schedules; they didn’t start by telling you where the train was going, they started by telling you what time the trains went out, and which track, the departure track. Further down was where the thing was going, if you took the time to read it all; it was a list of where the stops were, which is not the way to organise a timetable. The person rushing in to the station, the only thing he knows is where he is going, you want to be able to look up your destination and then see the time of the train, but it was exactly the other way around.

So Kenneth redesigned the timetable simply to improve it, so that ‘Where you are going comes first, and after that comes the time the train leaves’, and that is how all railway timetables are now organized.

Locomotive

The High Speed Train (HST) was a project developed within British Rail as a kind of internal company rival to the much-vaunted Advanced Passenger Train (APT) being developed during the same period, which used radical new technologies such as tilting carriages to increase running speeds. The APT project eventually failed altogether, whereas the HST, using evolutionary developments of conventional engineering (and some APT innovations), became hugely successful and, in its prototype version, with a Kenneth Grange-designed front end, set a world speed record for diesel locomotive traction of 230 kilometres per hour.

After some small jobs for British Rail, such as the timetable redesign, Kenneth Grange was approached by their Head of the Design Department, James Cousins, about ‘a paint job, the painting of the outside of a train’. This train was the new HST.

So I went in to see him and he had a model there, and it was a model of a very crude bullet-nosed train, and he said to me, This is being produced by the Engineering Department, this is the train they intend to make, but I can’t possibly let them get away with this awful paintwork. It had zig-zags on, and so he said, Please

DESIGNING TO PLEASE

come back with a proposal for the painting of this train. I went away and I did that but I also thought, I could improve the shape of this.

The brief, therefore, was for a styling contribution – a paint livery that might improve the appearance of the train. But Kenneth was not satisfied with such a restricted, paint job contribution; he wanted the styling to emerge from the function, and so, without telling his client, he found an aerodynamicist and managed to get use of a wind tunnel test facility at Imperial College, London, and began to make a series of models of the front of the train, gradually developing a better, more efficient, overall shape.

So bit by bit we developed an evolution of the shape of the train, based upon wind tunnel testing. I then went along to Cousins with this information and I said, Here’s some photos of a shape that’s not your bullet-nose, but it’s a shape that I think is much more elegant – and by the way, here’s the paint job. And he went into a meeting with the Board, and when this thing came up on the agenda he said, Here’s the model and here’s the livery I propose, but we have taken the liberty of doing some preliminary work on the shape; we believe that the shape proposed – nothing to do with the [engineering of the] running gear, with the actual motor, and so on – but we believe the shape actually could be more efficient. And he had the wind tunnel photographs and the Engineering Department had never been near a wind tunnel! I wish I had been in the meeting, I’m sure it was a real landmark meeting, when the Board was persuaded by these photos from the wind tunnel. Then afterwards he came out of the meeting and came back and said, Well, we have a job to do! But the rest was then relatively easy.

A successful prototype was developed to Kenneth’s design, but the story did not end there.

I had kept strictly within the technical terms of the brief. This dictated a window made of exceptionally strong flat glass, which severely limited its size, and a single driver’s seat positioned centrally. But instead of production going ahead with my design, a

65

chapters.title: Segment 10 (pages 78-86)
chapters.content:
66

DESIGN THINKING

disagreement arose between the union and management which resulted in a decision to position a driver and co-driver side by side. This had a profound effect on the design, since our aerodynamics, vindicated by the speed record, relied on a smooth flow of air to left and right of the front window.

There was a number of inter-related problems raised by the necessity of providing for two, side-by-side operators at the front of the cab, instead of the one central operator. The central, relatively small window in the prototype would have to be replaced by two windows with a central bar, and the extra window width inevitably flattened the front profile, thus reducing the aerodynamic efficiency. Even when the glassmakers found that a larger, single sheet of the toughened glass could be produced, the aerodynamic problem was still there.

One way of regaining the aerodynamic efficiency appeared to be to elongate and lower the rake of the cab front, so as to direct more air up and over the top rather than around the sides. But this option was denied by the technical requirement of providing the locomotive’s buffers at the front, which were located in a fixed position relative to the wheel bogies and could not be fully enclosed. Train buffers are necessary not, as is often thought, to cushion the train’s stop at the end of the track but to assist the locomotive to shunt carriages around in the assembling of complete trains.

Kenneth was unhappy about losing the aerodynamic efficiency

and pursued the matter with the railways’ chief engineer.

Credit is due to the chief engineer, because I wasn’t welcomed by these guys, but to this man’s everlasting credit I was sitting in a meeting with him, going over this fact that this new design was not as efficient as the one that they originally bought, and which had already set a world record. But there is no way you can have the geometry and have the wide window and get the same effect, and we were backwards and forwards over this. I suppose I knew that if we didn’t have buffers I’d get a different shape, so I said to him, Tell me again, tell me about buffers, how they work; thinking there might be some way I could sleek them in somehow or other. But you see, you’ve got this great plate and you’ve got probably fifteen inches of movement on the springs because of the shunting, and

DESIGNING TO PLEASE

all that’s got to be on its own stalk, you can’t have that inside a housing, really it’s got to be outside of the housing. And he said, Well, it is true that with this vehicle, which we’ve never, ever made before, we’ve never, ever made a train where the coaches are always attached, with this, of course, they’ll always stay coupled. And he said, So if it’s always coupled, it can’t be used for shunting, and therefore the only thing we need is a hard link. And so he said, So really we don’t need the buffers. To his credit he was prepared to say, We’ve overlooked it. They’d never, ever made a complete train like that before; they made locomotives, and they made carriages.

The HST was to be a fixed formation of passenger carriages between powercars at each end, which would not require shunting to assemble and disassemble trains. The development of the HST nose design is illustrated in Figure 3.4.

Kenneth’s perseverance had led to the vital breakthrough. The buffers on this locomotive for a new, permanently coupled train could be dispensed with. The aerodynamic efficiency could be retained by diverting the airflow from around the sides to over the top of a sleeker, more stylish, cab front. British Rail had a completely new, modern image, arising from its original request for ‘a paint job’. The HST train is still in service, and on its fortieth anniversary in 2016 one of the locomotives was named the ‘Sir Kenneth Grange’ in honour of its (recently knighted) designer (Figure 3.5).

The acceptance of the convention of having buffers on a locomotive is an example of fixation – a kind of unconscious, blinkered thinking in

FIGURE 3.4 Development of the nose of the High Speed Train to improve aerodynamics: (a) rounded nose with buffers; (b) raked nose without buffers. Courtesy of Kenneth Grange.

67

68

DESIGN THINKING

FIGURE 3.5 The British Rail High Speed Train. This particular HST power car is named the ‘Sir Kenneth Grange’ in honour of its designer. Photograph by Geof Sheppard – Own work, CC BY-SA 4.0, https:// commons .wikimedia .org /w /index .php ?curid =48649135.

which previous details just get copied over into new designs. In both the sewing machine and the high-speed train, Kenneth Grange was able to create innovative designs by questioning some conventional aspects of existing designs that were taken for granted as being essential. As Gordon Murray said, a creative designer has to keep their previous experience, and their knowledge of existing designs, at the back of their mind, not the front.

Case note: Fixation

Brian Meek was designing a new version of an existing,

successful fret saw for the Knew Concepts company. This kind of saw is used for precise, intricate cutting of wood and metal, for example in marquetry or jewellery, and its frame needs to be light and also stiff both longitudinally (along the blade) and in torsion (around the blade). The existing saw had a frame of titanium with holes cut into it to reduce weight (Figure 3.6.a). Because of rapidly rising material costs, Brian was looking for a new design that would use less material. A way to do that would be to assemble the saw from smaller, separate pieces, in place of the single-piece frame

DESIGNING TO PLEASE

cut from a large sheet of material. Brian began experimenting with making the frame from three separate pieces (two legs and the top) which could be cut with less waste from a smaller sheet of material. The problem then was how to join the pieces together into a form that was sufficiently stiff. A prototype was made with a two- piece top riveted to a pair of legs (Figure 3.6.b). Brian commented: ‘We tried for about six months to figure out some way to puzzle- piece a basically 2-D frame together, with no luck. Most of those designs were rigid in tension, but had no torsional rigidity at all.’

Then, in the midst of some tinkering, Brian almost accidentally came upon a three-dimensional truss structure. ‘I took home some test parts that I’d been fiddling with one night. I got completely sick of looking at them, and bent them outwards to form the basis of the truss that you now see [on the final product]. I zig-zagged a bit of strip across the top as bracing, just to see what would happen . . . Bingo! It didn’t deflect at all, and a design was born’ (Figure 3.6.c). The final design, with a more refined top part, was named the ‘birdcage saw’ (Figure 3.6.d).

FIGURE 3.6 Evolution of the fret saw frame: (a) the prior one-piece frame; (b) a multi-piece frame; (c) the top frame parts spread into a 3-D truss; (d) the final ‘birdcage’ design. Courtesy of Nathan Crilly. Drawings by Rob Woods.

69

70

DESIGN THINKING

Brian’s fixation had been due to a carry-over from the one-piece frame – seeing the separate frame pieces as a solid material with holes cut in it, until suddenly seeing the material around the holes as separate pieces of material joined together and thus potentially triangulated 3-D truss structures.

Source: Nathan Crilly and Roxana Moroşanu Firth: Creativity and fixation in the real world, Design Studies.

Learning from failure

Like Gordon Murray, Kenneth Grange is also ready to admit that he has produced some designs that failed and to hope that he has learned from such failures. He even mounted a whole exhibition of ‘Those that got away’ – more than forty design proposals and prototypes that were rejected by his clients or failed to go into manufacture, including a postmodern-styled toaster and a wine bottle shaped deliberately to provide a ‘glug’ sound as it poured. One of them was a design for the Channel Tunnel Eurostar train, running between Britain and continental Europe. Kenneth was one of four designers invited to submit proposals, and he felt confident of winning the competition, given his previous experience with the HST. He worked on two designs, one with a ‘bubble’ windscreen for the driver, and one much closer to the HST shape. He says that, ‘Because I thought the train was a sort of natural son of the HST, I abandoned the bubble idea’. But the competition was won by someone who produced a design based around just such a ‘bubble’ windscreen. Kenneth suspects that his design may have been rejected because it looked somewhat similar to his design of the earlier British HST train. ‘The real blunder for me was to have even thought of a reference to the HST. Clearly the French and the Belgian partners most certainly would not have wanted a son of the British national train on “their” railways!’

Another railway-related design failure for Kenneth was the ‘net chair’ he designed for British Rail. The goal was to produce a very

DESIGNING TO PLEASE

lightweight seat that would make a significant contribution to reducing the overall weight of a railway carriage, thereby reducing both capital and running costs. Kenneth found a net fabric used to make astronaut couches in spacecraft. Through a lot of experimentation with frames for holding this fabric, he produced a highly ergonomic, comfortable and very lightweight seat in which the stretched net fabric was the primary support for the user. But unfortunately the seat fabric was realized to be highly vulnerable to vandalism. Some train passengers were not the sort of people that Kenneth was seeking to please with his elegant design. ‘We had reckoned without the spite of the travelling yobbo who, with one quick slash of a knife, could destroy the seat.’ This was a lesson about realizing the whole wide range of people who are likely to be the ‘users’ of a new design.

Design process and working methods

The examples of the Frister & Rossman sewing machine and the British Rail High Speed Train illustrate Kenneth Grange’s approach to design, which seems predominantly to be based on generating style and form from function and use. This seems to be the natural way for him to work, even though his clients sometimes do not realize this, and approach him as a ‘stylist’. ‘They think’, he says,

We need a new design, we need a new style. They’re sharp enough to realise the style is outdated or whatever, and they assume because of what they have seen that it’s a purely artistic thing, it’s a fashion thing only to do with style. I can’t get to a solution from that beginning, so I start entirely from the point of view of, can I make the use of the thing better. Eventually, by some extraordinary piece of good fortune, I wind up with a style that they think is terrific and how it got there they are not interested. It does become interesting when we then start to develop it because I find I’m defending bits of the mechanical process and they don’t want me to, particularly the engineers don’t want me to!

He says he always has a concern with ‘the nitty-gritty’ of products and their use, including not only their primary function but also

71

72

DESIGN THINKING

secondary aspects such as their cleaning. And yet he rejects what he sometimes sees in others as ‘a highly moral stance where function is all’. There has been a temptation, he says, for some designers ‘to scorn the elements of style, fashion and pleasure. That, in my view, is the road to righteous boredom’. His view is that ‘Design should solve a problem, work well, last, and, of course, look good’.

In addition to this personal commitment, however, he frequently refers to the ‘happy accidents’ that seem to have dominated his career.

I keep saying accident, but it is – I happen to be on the scene when people need a particular skill, and I am of the good fortune to be on the doorstep, passing the front door when that particular skill is needed. An example of this casualness, as I call it, is in both the train and in the design I did for the Chef [the Kenwood Chef food mixer – one of Kenneth’s earliest and most well-known designs, Figure 3.7], which eventually led me to 35 years of working with Kenwood. I got the job of designing the Chef because I said I’d do it in three days, and my fee was probably the lowest of the three people they were talking to. And the casualness, by which the thing was accepted, and then goes into production, and my whole life opens up, is that with only three days in which to do it, and the only method I knew, because I’d never had any training as a designer, although a good draughtsman I’d never had any of the skilful training about presentation drawing, so I wasn’t good at flashy drawings and things and I did everything with model making, every single thing I did with model making because I could do it, personally do it. But I didn’t have enough time, I only had time enough to make half a model, just could not make a whole model, so I made a half and I took a mirror with me [to place alongside to give the effect of seeing the symmetrical whole]. Now, it wasn’t artifice on my part, at least it wasn’t a trick, it was just a practical way of showing them a whole thing with half the effort. Kenneth Wood [the company owner] loved it, and I think he loved it because he thought it was salesmanship. For me, it was a pure bit of good luck.

DESIGNING TO PLEASE

FIGURE 3.7 The Kenwood Chef kitchen machine was one of Kenneth Grange’s earliest and most successful designs. As the form is symmetrical about the vertical lengthwise midline it enabled him to make a half model and place a mirror against it to demonstrate the overall form to his client. Courtesy of Kenwood Limited.

73

74

chapters.title: Segment 11 (pages 87-94)
chapters.content:
4

How designers think

In this chapter I will first summarize and compare the observations

that can be made and the lessons that can be drawn from the case studies of Gordon Murray and Kenneth Grange. Although their examples stem from very different domains of design – Formula One, city car, sewing machine, locomotive – the two designers can be seen to have similarities in their approaches. Some of these similarities seem to stem from their backgrounds and personalities, and they obviously share personal, highly motivated attitudes towards their work and the achievement of success. I will compare their approaches with those of other successful designers and offer an overview of the strategic thinking practices that appear to be common to these designers. I will also introduce some other studies that focus on the nature of creative thinking in design.

Motivation and attitude

Gordon Murray thinks that innovative design, certainly in motor racing, starts with ‘a certain type of person’, like himself, who has a strong desire to beat the opposition: ‘All you want to do is go back next time and blow them all into the weeds.’ Not all racing car designers are like that, he agrees, but he has always had that strong competitive urge. The strength of his personal motivation cannot be doubted; it would have been essential to carry him through so many innovations, through failures as well as successes, in such a highly

76

DESIGN THINKING

pressured environment. He has also had a strong personal interest and practical involvement in motor racing and car design throughout his life, including designing, building and racing his own sports car as a young man. The novel three-seat driver/passengers layout of the McLaren F1, used again in the city car, in which the driver is central and two passengers are side by side slightly behind the driver, is something that appeared in his design sketchbooks as a young man, and he says that other ideas are still there in his various sketchbooks waiting for an opportunity to be realized.

Kenneth Grange’s approach to design also seems to be rooted in his early experiences of ‘learning by doing’ – of learning to take apart and re-assemble artillery mechanisms so that he could make the drawings that would explain to someone else how to do it. Another relevant aspect of his time in the Army, he believes, was that it helped develop his physical health and strength, which he regards as a key to the hard work and long hours he later put into building and running his design practice. This physical aptitude is part of the strength of leadership, he believes:
