Designing together

The case study in this chapter is based on the same experiment

as in the previous one but provides a quite different perspective on the design process. In this experiment, a small team of three designers tackled the same design problem as did Victor Scheinman in the previous one, a carrying/fastening device for transporting a hiker’s backpack on a mountain bicycle and in the same two-hour experiment situation. However, this was not a ‘think-aloud’ protocol study, but all the team’s actions and natural conversation verbalizations were recorded for analysis. Because it involves teamwork, the design process in this case study has some significant differences from the previous study. Teamwork is of considerable importance in normal professional design activity and has become of even greater importance as design becomes a more integrated and inclusive activity involving collaboration amongst many different professions, and extended into co-designing with other project stakeholders such as clients and potential end-users. Understanding how design thinking operates in a teamwork context is therefore fundamental. The team in this study were three experienced product designers from the California office of the international, renowned design consultancy IDEO, who volunteered to participate in the experiment.

Teamwork in design

Working as a member of a team introduces different problems and possibilities for the designer, in comparison with working alone. An

112

DESIGN THINKING

obvious difference from single-person work is that the team members have roles and relationships within the team, relative to each other. In a normal work situation, some of these roles and relationships may be formally established; for instance, there may be seniorities of position established within the team, there may be a team leader appointed by a higher authority within the organization and there may be particular job roles or specialisms.

Whether working alone or in a team, it would seem necessary to have to plan one’s activities to fit within the available time. This may be easier for an individual than for a team, but in fact explicit planning of activities is not always evident in either individual or teamwork. Furthermore, it seems to be necessary in design for unplanned, ad hoc exploratory activities to be pursued when they are perceived as relevant by the designer. This particular team did explicitly plan its activities, but if unplanned, exploratory activities are a normal feature of design activity, it becomes interesting to see how planned and unplanned actions are handled within a team.

As we have seen, it is also normal, indeed necessary, in design to interpret and re-formulate the problem given as the task. The nature of design problems means that analysing and understanding the problem is an influential part of the design process. Individual designers can form their own, possibly idiosyncratic interpretation of the problem, but a team has to reach some shared or commonly held understanding of the problem.

Furthermore, in any design task, information relevant to the task has to be gathered from a variety of sources. A particular feature of the experiment design of this study was that a file of information on aspects of the problem was held by the experimenter, with relevant segments to be given to the designers if and when they asked for particular information. This helped to make explicit and observable some aspects of the necessary gathering and sharing of information that any team would have to undertake.

Since a design task also means that the goal is to produce a design proposal, it is necessary to generate some ideas or concepts for what that proposal might be. An advantage of teamwork over individual work might be that a greater number and variety of concepts are generated. Again, in teamwork it will be necessary to communicate and share such concepts and ideas. It will be interesting to see how

DESIGNING TOGETHER

activities of proposing and developing design concepts are handled in teamwork.

A disadvantage of teamwork is likely to be that conflicts may arise between team members. Different interpretations or understandings of the problem may become evident, and different design concepts may be favoured by different members of the team. An inevitable part of design teamwork would therefore seem to be identifying, avoiding and resolving conflicts.

These aspects of teamwork will be considered here in the context of the experimental study, drawing on examples of how these issues became manifest in the team’s design activities.

It is quite normal for designers to become emotionally involved with their ideas; their design concepts are not merely abstract ideas, but personal insights that emerge as a result of some considerable cognitive effort. It is no wonder that these conceptual ‘babies’ are defended against other, competing concepts. This emotional commitment has to be recognized and allowed for in teamwork; creative design is unlikely to happen without it. However, team members also have to be able to recognize that some suggested concepts are just jokes (‘Harry the backpack holder’), or half-serious ideas that are intended to help the creative process along and to which the originator has no serious commitment.

Avoiding and resolving conflicts

It is probably inevitable that disagreement will arise between members of a design team. We have already seen that disagreement

DESIGNING TOGETHER

arose within this team over whether to use the existing brazed-on mounting points. More serious disagreement might have arisen if there had been competing design concepts to which different members of the team were committed. However, provided that a team collectively desires to reach an acceptable conclusion to their design task, it will have to find ways of resolving, or perhaps avoiding conflicts.

In this team, there were instances where the team members acquiesced in a kind of non-committal ‘agreement’ until one of them found an argument that closed the disagreement, and others where they postponed agreement and seemed to ‘agree to disagree’. For example, a disagreement became evident over designing for adjustability in the rack. John proposed that the support legs of the rack should be adjustable, but Kerry felt sure that this was not necessary:

These examples of deferred agreement or non-committal apparent agreement reflect normal aspects of human discussion and verbal interchange. But design team members need to be aware of when they are close to reaching actual agreement and when they are just deferring making a committed agreement. Even when there is no overt disagreement, individuals may still nurse a contrary viewpoint and return to it when the opportunity arises.

Discussion: Design cooperation

The picture that emerges from this study is probably typical of normal team design activity. We have seen how the design process

DESIGNING TOGETHER

proceeds by sequences of both planned and unplanned activities; how frequently there may be mistakes and misunderstandings of the brief and external information sources; how the design problem becomes understood in terms of solution concepts that are proposed and developed in a mixture of personal and cooperative endeavour; how emotional commitment becomes attached to design concepts; how conflicts of ideas arise between team members; and how such conflicts are resolved or deferred.

It is clear that teamwork is a cooperative social process, and therefore social interactions, roles and relationships cannot be ignored in cases of design activity performed by teams. It is a collaborative process and, in this study, the conventional whiteboard and drawing paper tools allowed, and were used for, shared drawing and listing activities, including different team members drawing and re-drawing over shared sketches. This sharing of representations seems fundamental to collaborative design activity. We will explore more of these issues around team working and collaborative designing in the next chapter.

Given some apparent inconsistencies and difficulties in the progress of this design team, it is perhaps important to conclude with the observation that this particular group of designers was actually a very good team. They worked cooperatively and productively, and reached a successful conclusion to the set task, within the prescribed time. Despite some of the observations made about the roles, relationships and social interactions within the team, there were no overt signs of frustration or dissatisfaction within individual members of the team. In the debriefing after the experiment they reported that they were reasonably happy with what they had achieved in the available time, and that ‘it was fun’.

How designers work

In the previous two chapters we have looked quite closely into the

details of how designers actually tackle a design problem. This was made possible through the use of laboratory ‘protocol study’ experiments that were in many senses far removed from the reality of everyday design practice. In this chapter, I will develop a broader summary and comparison of these two experimental studies, and try to draw evidence and conclusions about the way designers work when confronted with a design task. The fact that these two experimental studies have been the subjects of detailed analysis by several researchers (in an international conference on Analysing Design Activity) will help to make the comparisons and summaries, but first we must acknowledge the problems and limitations of such studies.

It was clear in some of Victor Scheinman’s ‘think aloud’ statements that he felt constrained in the experimental situation; for example, he referred to what he would do in a normal situation, such as call an expert friend, but which wasn’t possible to do in the experimental situation. (He did manage to go ‘outside’ of the experimental situation and do something that surprised the experimenters, when he telephoned for advice from a company making similar products.) However, there were other, more subtle clues within the recordings of the experiment that indicated that we cannot rely totally on ‘think-aloud’ statements as records of mental processes. Some researchers have pointed out that non-verbal thought seems to be intrinsic to design thinking and that the forced verbalization of protocol studies must interfere with non-verbal thought processes.

134

DESIGN THINKING

It was also clear that there were many points in Victor’s stream of comments where his verbalizations stopped for several seconds. On one occasion, he had to be prompted by the experimenter to resume his thinking aloud. Commenting on Victor’s silent moments, Peter Lloyd and his colleagues suggested that ‘it seems obvious that in these short periods of silence he is thinking deeply about something’, and that these silent periods ‘seem to be points of value where decisions are made, but we have no idea of the thinking behind these decisions’.

So we have to be careful about drawing very strong conclusions about deep cognitive processes from such experiments, in which a designer works alone and tries to verbalize their thinking. The second experiment, in which the three-person team of designers worked more naturally, although still within tight experimental constraints, obviously also contains many gaps in the individual thought processes, when a team member is silent, where again we can make little assumption about what the individual was thinking. However, there are lots of useful observations that can be made from such experiments as these, and in fact both these experiments have been analysed quite considerably and in depth by a number of independent researchers.

Creative working

We have seen previously, in Chapter 1 and the earlier case studies, that experienced, successful designers have ways of working that enable them to reach creative insights and make promising conjectures that drive the design process forward. Whilst maintaining a deep involvement with details within a particular project, they also have a way of keeping up an apparently higher level of awareness for spotting constructive opportunities that may emerge during the process. In Victor Scheinman’s design work there were several points at which he clearly recognized breakthroughs or significant concept generation points, using expressions such as ‘Ah-ha!’ and ‘Good idea!’ These expressions indicate that he feels he is ‘on to something’, that a way forward is opening up.

HOW DESIGNERS WORK

Ömer Akin and Chengtah Lin analysed Victor’s work and identified a number of what they called ‘novel design decisions’: that is, non-routine decisions that ‘turn out to be critical for the progress of the entire design’. Whilst there was a large number of ‘routine’ design decisions in Victor’s protocol, Akin and Lin identified just ten novel design decisions (NDDs), which were characterized by three features: an NDD resolves a problem or bottleneck, it does not follow from previous assumptions and the designer identifies the NDD as an important feature of the overall design. A particular example is the emergence of Victor’s decision to base his design on a triangular frame, when he said: ‘It would be nice if I could, for instance, run these rods up here to some point and therefore create a triangle, this would give me great stiffness – good idea!’

Akin and Lin sorted Victor’s working activities into three categories: examining (such as reading information, inspecting the available bike or backpack), thinking (whether verbalized or silent) and drawing. They then went on to record the frequency with which Victor switched between these activities and found an interesting correlation between the frequency of switching and the occurrence of NDDs. In almost all cases, they found Victor was alternating between the three activity modes in rapid succession at the point of reaching a novel design decision. Akin and Lin were rightly cautious about drawing any inference that rapid succession between different activities actually causes or produces NDDs. Their observation was only that the two seem to go together. They concluded only that ‘Our data suggest that designers explore their domain of ideas in a variety of activity modes when they go beyond routine decisions and achieve design breakthroughs’, and that ‘The designer appears to be decidedly engaged in all three major activities at the time of the NDD’. What their analysis suggests is that a designer’s level of engagement rises, and they work across a wider span of attention to different facets of the problem and solution, as they sense the achievement of a critical, creative point in the process.

Some other studies have also noted the apparent importance of frequent shifts of attention or between activity modes in influencing either the creativity or overall quality of the design concepts produced. For example, in protocol studies of industrial design students, Henri Christiaans segmented the students’ activities into the three modes

135

136

DESIGN THINKING

of gathering information, sketching and reflecting. He suggested that the students who were more successful in producing creative design concepts were those who showed evidence of rapid alternation between the activity modes. Also, Cindy Atman and her colleagues, from studies of engineering design students, found that the overall quality of the design concepts that the students generated was related to evidence of more fluid and rapid transitions occurring between different activities in the design process, such as gathering information, generating ideas and modelling. We will look at these findings in more depth in Chapter 8.

Of course, there can be no suggestion of causality; simply flitting more quickly between activity types is not necessarily going to help a designer to be more creative. It seems rather that creative working is associated with a high level of concentration and engagement, especially at points when a designer senses a critical moment in the progress of the project.

Team working

Design work is rarely a matter of a single individual working alone, as in the protocol study of Victor Scheinman. A lot of designing involves collaboration with other people, such as specialist consultants, clients or potential customers for a new product, and most design work takes place in a collaborative studio environment with and alongside colleagues. In a study of graphic designers, for example, Dianne Murray recorded the very social nature of design in practice and emphasized the openness and richness of activities within a design studio: ‘Briefing sessions take place in the studio in clear sight and sound of everyone. Work in progress is left on drawing boards; discarded sketches, photocopies, printouts and transparencies are left lying around on desks or on the light box.’ She commented that ‘Design is not hidden, it is constructed in public so other people can read it, and accepting commentary on it from somebody else is part of a tradition they embody’.

So a valuable aspect of the teamwork study here is that it enables us to observe how designers work together with one another. We have seen in that experiment how the three designers successfully worked

HOW DESIGNERS WORK

together collectively, whilst tending to play somewhat different roles. Some researchers who analysed this experiment noted the different styles and approaches that were shown by the three, and especially the differences between Kerry’s and John’s approaches. Particularly in the early part of the session, Kerry tended to want to gather specific information and to engage with the available hardware and some of its details, whereas John tended to want to step back from details, work at a more general level of the overall process and gain a broad view of the problem.

The different approaches of Kerry and John were summarized by Margot Brereton and her colleagues as wanting to pin down a solution (Kerry) and wanting to preserve ambiguity (John) (Table 7.1). Having two such complementary emphases within a team can be good, but of course it has to be managed to avoid conflict and achieve a constructive outcome. Brereton pointed out that, to resolve or avoid conflict, ‘The designers masterfully invoke the support of neutral parties such as common sense, higher principles or theories, and expert or standard practices to support their opinions. These serve to depersonalise the debate, in addition to being means of persuasion and explanation of rationale.’ These experienced designers seem to have had some effective strategies for working together that built on each other’s preferences for ways of approaching the design task. Brereton concluded that ‘the collaboration is successful because the group is well balanced in their roles and manages their negotiation well. Kerry seeks to pin down solution alternatives, John seeks to preserve ambiguity and characterize the ongoing process, and Ivan keeps the solution progress on track and acts as an arbitrator between John and Kerry’ (Table 7.2).

Despite the differences between the individual designers, analyses of the experiment have shown that their individual contributions to the session, whilst different in content, were quite similar in terms of quantity. Whilst John produced more solution variant ideas, equal to those of the other two together, all three contributed equally in analysis comments on solution variants, and John and Kerry each contributed exactly the same number of decisions in choosing between solution variants (Ivan rather less). An individual designer working alone has no one to collaborate with, so how does the work of an individual designer compare with that of a team? These two experiments, using the same design task, allow us to make such a comparison, and the question was explicitly addressed in an analysis by Gabriela Goldschmidt. She pointed out that the cognitive tasks within design can be shared out between team members, whereas a designer working on their own has to produce the full range of tasks of inquiring, formulating, suggesting, evaluating, modifying and so on. She compared several key sequences of activity between Victor and the team, and found some significant similarities, with Victor’s activities often ‘shadowing’ those of the team. She observed that

He oscillates between overviews and technical details, between functional aspects of the design product and issues related to human factors. He thinks of features, product identity and aesthetics along with stiffness, strength and ease of production.

Team members do the same, but they can let a colleague answer a question they raise, or pick up someone else’s line of thought and build on it. The single designer has only him or herself to rely on, and he or she must act as a team and give all the answers while also asking all the questions.

These comments indicate some of the complexity that there is in the task of designing. Goldschmidt’s conclusion is that Victor implicitly ‘plays’ several roles and acts as ‘a team of one’, as in this extract from his think-aloud comments about adding some plastic clips to his rack design that would grip and hold the backpack frame: ‘Why do we want clips? Because we want to take advantage of the fact we’re using an external-frame backpack. An internal frame can’t use clips.’ Here, she suggests, Victor1 asks, Victor2 answers and Victor3 gives the design rationale. In this, there is an echo of designers ‘talking to themselves’ implicitly through their drawings and in their scribbled comments. In both Victor’s and the team processes there are also echoes and perhaps a confirmation of Donald Schön’s characterization of design as ‘a reflective conversation with the situation’.

Team leadership

Some of the researchers who analysed the team’s work regarded John as acting in a ‘team leader’ role, partly because he seemed to be the ‘ideas person’ but also because he would make comments intended to focus and direct the conversation. Ivan also showed leadership in organizing the process by acting as whiteboard manager and timekeeper. We do not know what relationships or roles the team members may have brought with them from their normal work environment (they were all members of the same large design office), so there might have been some built-in hierarchies within the team. In some situations the leader might be pre-assigned to that role, or it might emerge informally through the course of a teamwork project. However, most real-world design teams do have some form of hierarchy, particularly where one member is clearly identified as being the team leader. That person is usually charged

139

140

DESIGN THINKING

with responsibility for achieving a satisfactory outcome and steering the progress towards that outcome.

Leadership is not just a matter of being a dominant personality, or ‘having the most to say’. Andy Dong made a very detailed analysis of the conversational patterns of this team and others in similar experiments, and suggested that the constructive influence of a member in a design team is due to the way they interact with the others and articulate shared concepts. He observed that, ‘while John is a productive individual idea generator, he also builds upon Ivan’s and Kerry’s ideas’. For example, Dong refers to points in the conversation where John ‘accumulates the discourse’ and characterizes a shared concept at that point, such as ‘maybe it’s a pack conversion kit’ or ‘maybe it’s a little vacuum-formed tray’. To ‘accumulate the discourse’ means not just to sum up but to make a constructive contribution that focuses the previous discussion onto a type of solution concept and suggests a way forward. Dong referred to this as ‘deriving a representation of the team’s shared language that frames the design concept’.

However, in successful team design work, this constructive approach is not due to just one member of the team. Dong also looked at other teams and found that, in the more successful teams, the whole pattern of their conversation was more focused. A successful team’s discussion showed more ‘coherent’ development, in which the team members built upon each other’s contributions, progressing in a coherent form of conversation. The evidence for this lay in measuring how closely team members’ contributions to the discussion followed on from previous contributions, rather than diverging from them.

The importance and the nature of the role played by a team leader were identified by Chih-Chun Chen and colleagues in a study of a team of experienced designers in a real-world, cross-cultural (Europe/ China) automotive accessories design project. Their conclusion was that ‘the role of a leader in collaborative design can be vital to team success’. This success is based on how the team leader controls team progress by coordinating team discussions, helping the team to build up shared understandings of the problem situation and to collaborate in accumulating and progressing solution ideas. They suggested that team leadership shapes collaborative designing

HOW DESIGNERS WORK

through two principal mechanisms: guiding the team’s design process strategy and ensuring effective communication within the team. A key aspect of effective communication is the role of the leader as a ‘communication hub’, receiving ideas and opinions from team members and relaying them back to the speaker and the rest of the team for clarification, exploration and confirmation. For this to be effective, team members need to feel comfortable in sharing their comments and proposals; when a team is working well members do not respond negatively to each other’s comments and proposals but by proposing re-interpretations or constructive alternatives.

From their study of teamwork in medical product design, mentioned in Chapter 4 with respect to co-evolution, Stefan Wiltschnig and his colleagues also emphasized the role of the team leader in initiating constructive, co-evolutionary creative design episodes. This was particularly so with regard to making changes in the initial problem requirements that subsequently led to solution proposals. These initiatives were often purposefully introduced by the team leader. Witschnig reported that ‘many design conversations were initiated by the team leader mentioning or amending a design requirement. Other members of the design team would then contribute useful ideas, either by way of developing the interpretation of the requirement or by way of generating and evaluating solution possibilities.’

An example of this was an episode initiated by team leader K and progressed by team member M. They are discussing product features for the ease and safety of use in a type of ostomy bag, which is worn by the user to hold fluid draining from their body:

K: What else have we got . . . we’ve talked about whether we could do something to avoid making it impossible to fold it this way. But that’s a problem for

M: The ones who’d like to – yes, it’s a problem for those who want to fold it that way while emptying. If you could make something so it was not so high up

K: So you couldn’t fold it

Here, team leader K initiates a discussion on how the user might mishandle the bag and how the fastening of the bag might be designed to prevent that. Team member M confirms the problem and suggests

DESIGN THINKING

not a specific idea but a generic approach of making it ‘not so high up’, and K confirms the implicit intention of making the mishandling impossible. Over the next few minutes the team pursued a string of related solution suggestions involving changing the bag closure in several ways to overcome the folding issue, such as incorporating colour coding or adding text, or changing the user instruction manual.

The researchers commented that ‘These episodes did not seem to involve great leaps in creative discovery regarding how the formulation of the problem should change, but rather entailed minor increments being introduced by the team leader in order to change the focus to another part of the design problem space.’ However, they added that the team leader’s role ‘seems to be vital for the achievement of organisational goals relating to the delivery of high-quality, innovative design solutions’. In initiating and coordinating changes of focus the team leader is performing acts of metacognition – which means thinking about one’s own thinking or reflecting on the team’s process and progress and making changes as necessary. Individual designers working alone also perform these acts of metacognition in working as a ‘team of one’.

Design process

Experienced designers know that it is possible to go on almost forever gathering information and data about a design problem, but that they have to move on to generating solution proposals, which in themselves begin to indicate what is relevant information. In a design project it is often not at all clear what ‘the problem’ is; it may have been only loosely defined by the client, many constraints and criteria may be undefined and everyone involved in the project may know that goals may be redefined during the project. In designing, ‘problems’ are often defined in relation to ideas for their ‘solution’, and designers do not typically proceed by first attempting to define their problems rigorously, which they know may be impossible. Of course, this can mean that important information is overlooked or might be discovered only very late in the design process, causing disruption and delay. For these reasons, there have been attempts to set out formal, metacognitive models of an ideal design process and

HOW DESIGNERS WORK

suggestions for methodologies or structured approaches that should lead designers efficiently towards a good solution.

It is therefore interesting that, in our team design experiment, the team did set out a model for their process and tried to stick to it. Their model process consisted of the following stages:

Quantify the problem Generate concepts Refine concepts Select a concept Design Present

Some analysts have looked at the actual process that the team (and Victor) followed. For example, Joachim Günther and colleagues analysed the individual statements in the team’s conversations into three types, concerned with (1) clarifying the task, (2) searching for concepts and (3) fixing the concept. What the team was actually doing through this period was generating lots of partial concepts and then considering the implications of those concepts. In that way they were exploring the problem through possible solutions. It might seem surprising that ‘clarifying the task’ is an activity that recurs throughout so much of the session, as it did in the team’s process. But it is quite normal in the design process that there is an ongoing interactive, co-evolutionary exploration and development of both the problem and the solution. A pattern similar to this team’s activity pattern has been found in other studies and is not a-typical. For example, Vinod Goel found, in protocol studies of architectural design, that ‘problem structuring’ could constitute as much as 30 per cent of the overall task time, and although it was concentrated near the beginning of the task it could recur constantly until almost the very end of the session.

A concern with user issues was more evident in Victor’s process than it was in that of the team. He ‘internalized’ the problem information, rather than making

In fact, much of his design activity was similar to that of the team, in that he made progress by proposing a partial solution concept and then analysing its strengths and weaknesses.

Victor commented at one point that ‘scheduling my time on these things, that’s the hard part’, and he frequently commented on the time constraint he was working under. Organizing a design process is quite a difficult task, because there has to be allowance for free- flowing activity within an overall schedule of things to be done within a time limit. The team’s design process seemed quite complex; it was free-flowing, but it was also quite controlled. Brereton et al. concluded that ‘the designers are continuously engaged in multiple activities at different levels. Although they focus in on issues, they continuously monitor the progress of the solution from the point of view of various requirements and solution alternatives. They reflect on their course of action, monitoring and modifying their process.’

The differences, such as they are, between the design processes of Victor and the team seem to be more to do with the differences between individual and team working processes. Victor was ‘a team of one’ and he was not subject to the pressures and constraints of working with other people, such as we considered in the analysis of teamwork in the previous chapter.

Structure versus spontaneity

Some other studies have identified that designers usually start with a structured plan for their design process, as our team did, but frequently slip from the plan into opportunistic pursuit of issues or partial solutions that catch the designer’s attention, again as our team did. It has been argued that opportunistic behaviour, often derogatorily regarded elsewhere, is appropriate behaviour for designers because it allows the flexibility to deal with design

145

146

DESIGN THINKING

problems and the ‘opportunities’ that emerge in the design process. For example, Willemien Visser made a study of an experienced mechanical engineering designer who claimed to be following a structured approach, but Visser found frequent deviations from this plan. She noted that ‘The engineer had a hierarchically structured plan for his activity, but he used it in an opportunistic way. He used it only as long as it was profitable from the point of view of cognitive cost. If more economical cognitive actions arose, he abandoned it.’ Thus Visser regarded reducing ‘cognitive cost’ – that is the mental load of maintaining a principled, structured approach – as a major reason for abandoning planned actions and instead, for example, delving into pursuing a partial solution at a relatively early stage of the process.

Raymonde Guindon also emphasized the opportunistic nature of design activities, which was evident in her protocol studies of three experienced software system designers. Guindon stressed that ‘designers frequently deviate from a top-down approach. These results cannot be accounted for by a model of the design process where problem specification and understanding precedes solution development and where the design solution is elaborated at successively greater levels of detail in a top-down manner.’ Guindon observed the interleaving of problem specification with solution development, ‘drifting’ through partial solution development, and jumps into exploring suddenly recognized partial solutions, which were categorized as major causes of ‘opportunistic solution development’. However, rather than regarding this opportunism as a weak feature of design behaviour, Guindon suggested it might be inevitable, because ‘These deviations are not special cases due to bad design habits or performance breakdowns but are, rather, a natural consequence of the ill-structuredness of problems in the early stages of design’. Like Visser, Guindon also referred to ‘cognitive cost’ as one possible explanation for such behaviour: ‘Designers find it advantageous to follow a train of thought temporarily, thus arriving at partial solutions at little cognitive cost.’

Clearly, whether it’s a single designer or a design team they have to monitor and adjust their own design process as they move through a project; they must occasionally take a step back from the activities they are directly engaged in to reflect on their progress. Dagny Valgeirsdottir and Balder Onarheim studied a team working

HOW DESIGNERS WORK

in automotive design and observed that ‘Process awareness is a cognitive creativity skill that individuals in a design team use to facilitate a creative process’. They identified the operation of this metacognitive skill occurring where someone in the team uses phrases such as ‘we need to’, ‘we should’, ‘I think we’ or words related to process awareness such as ‘insight’, ‘focus’, ‘fixated’ or ‘incubation’. In the short account earlier of the problem of users potentially mishandling an ostomy bag, the team leader initiated a change of focus with the phrase ‘so what have we got?’, suggesting a summarizing and progress review point in the process.

Collaborative designing

It seems especially hard in teamwork to follow a tightly prescribed process because individual members may have individual preferences for ways of working. There is often a natural flow to design processes that can run counter to a prescription for what should happen when. The team process in collaborative designing therefore requires particular attention to how natural conversation can be guided into a constructive, productive and creative process. One means of helping to do this is to externalize aspects of the conversation into a shared public space.

We saw in our team design experiment how they used a whiteboard for listing process steps, problem structures and solution ideas. The whiteboard is a means of externalizing and recording thoughts, and also supports moments of reflection when the team pauses and considers what they have on the whiteboard. Through this kind of externalizing, a design team is able to share and deal with complex structures and relationships that are very difficult or impossible to hold solely within the brain. The use of sticky notes, either on a whiteboard or some other flat surface, has now become almost ubiquitous in team processes of all kinds for this kind of externalization. In design teamwork, they have joined other common supportive media for designing such as sketching, modelling and prototyping.

The use of sticky notes in collaborative design has been studied to identify how they support particular aspects of design thinking.

147

148

DESIGN THINKING

Linden Ball and his colleagues pointed out that ‘sticky notes can be used quickly, easily and informally to generate many potentially relevant – albeit somewhat disconnected – ideas without designers needing to possess full insight into where the generated information might be leading. In a short amount of time a blank workspace can thus become populated with a multitude of visually distinct ideas’. They argued that ‘to disregard the humble sticky note as a key support material in creative design is to ignore a whole sphere of cognition that underpins effective real-world design practice’.

Ball suggested that the properties of sticky notes make them not just an easy means of recording and structuring ideas, but that they are inherently supportive of design thinking in collaborative processes. The visual and adjustable display of sticky notes supports perceptions and other cognitive design processes in identifying and modifying conceptual relations amongst the parts to form wholes. Ball proposed that the use of sticky notes makes it possible for a design team ‘(i) to consider the parts as “variables” in a system, thereby enabling the exchange of parts, while retaining the structural whole; (ii) to restructure the whole representation into new representations by re-configuring the parts; and (iii) to explore and establish dynamically new possible structural links to existing concepts, thereby gradually and generatively “building-up” or advancing a conceptual whole with new emergent properties’. That outline might be regarded as offering a neat summary not only of collaborative designing processes but also of design thinking more generally. Like drawing and sketching in design (as I commented in Chapter 4), sticky notes permit and encourage simultaneous, non-hierarchical participation in collaborative designing, using a common representation.

Frequently, collaborative designing includes designers working with a wide range of participants or stakeholders, including end-users of the proposed design result. This involves different attitudes towards and patterns of design activity that have to be accommodated within the design process. In user-centred workshops in communication design for sustainable cleaning in childcare centres and for asthma management and awareness, Simone Taffe found that non-designer participants were happy to engage in idea generation but reluctant to evaluate the collected ideas. For example, ‘the childcare staff were reluctant to place evaluation dots on the cleaning moodboard

HOW DESIGNERS WORK

as they did not want to criticise their co-workers’ ideas or have any form of disagreement about their co-created posters’. She also found that a ranking method often used by communication designers was resisted by the asthma staff because

the words to be sorted presented a mix of negative and positive issues. Seeing printed cards displaying the negative aspects of [their own] work practices created an immediate barrier for the asthma staff, preventing them from participating in the card ranking activity. The designer technique of ranking was perceived as confrontational whereas discussion was more conducive to forming a consensus towards good ideas.

Collaborative designing is therefore clearly a social process and so progress can be influenced by normal issues of social interaction, such as reluctance to criticize others in a group. Externalizing aspects of the process, through the use of whiteboards, idea cards, sticky notes and other modelling, is a way of opening up the design process and making social interaction cooperative and creative. However, collaborative designing has to be carefully managed to create a successful process of social and creative interaction that enhances group knowledge and skill.

Creative designing

In making an analysis of our backpack-carrier team design experiment, David Radcliffe spotted a weakness in the team’s process that constrained their creativity. They decomposed the overall problem into sub-problems of joining ‘pack to rack’ and ‘rack to bike’, as shown in Ivan’s whiteboard lists of the various concepts (Figure 6.4). At the core of their problem structuring was the concept of a ‘rack’. But the design brief that the team was given asked for ‘a carrying/fastening device’ – something much more open than directly specifying ‘a rack’. This particular interpretation severely limited much of the team’s exploration of the problem.

Radcliffe noticed that this decomposition of the problem made it difficult for the team to consider solution concepts that arose naturally

149

150

DESIGN THINKING

in the conversation but that did not fit the agreed decomposition. At separate times both Kerry and John commented on the fact that the existing external frame of the backpack was in itself a structure something like a rack. Kerry commented that ‘We’ve already got that frame on the pack; it would be nice if we can take advantage of that’. A little later, John commented that ‘there’s a kind of other class of solutions outside of our design problem [structure], and that’s that you could somehow use the external frame and wouldn’t need the rack’. Just a little later again, Kerry formulated a solution concept for a simple device, suggesting that ‘maybe the attachment is kind of a leg that attaches right to the external frame’. Radcliffe notes that, ‘Ivan records the concept on the whiteboard as “legs on frame” under the “pack to rack” heading . . . There is no explicit acknowledgement that this concept falls outside the pack-to-rack/rack-to-bike dichotomy. In terms of the recorded work of the team, listing concepts under suitably decomposed headings takes precedence over capturing less structured or controllable emergence of design ideas.’

A ‘no-rack’ concept clearly does not fit anywhere within the team’s problem decomposition. Although the team went on to consider some more ideas for such a ‘no-rack’ concept, eventually it was lost as they returned to their more orderly sequence of planned activities. This loss of a potentially radical, creative solution was precisely due to the team creating, and sticking to, a specific structuring of the problem. In collaborative and co-designing, which often has a broad brief and can include heterogeneous teams comprising not only designers but also clients, customers and other specialists, leaving the problem structure as open as possible for as long as possible can help to avoid premature fixation and the unnecessary restriction of solution types.

David Radcliffe also concluded from his analysis that the team’s progress to a solution concept demonstrated that the emergence of creative ideas cannot be constrained to a particular place or sequence within a design process. He pointed out, ‘It is clear that design ideas emerge where they will in the continuum of the design conversation . . . Ideation cannot be constrained to occur only during the prescribed time for this activity as dictated by notions of due process and proper sequence of phases in design.’ To provide a specific emphasis, Radcliffe pointed out that the team’s decisive ‘tray’ concept was

HOW DESIGNERS WORK

generated during what was supposed to be the evaluation phase to ‘select a concept’.

The creative bridge

There seemed to be the classic notion of a ‘creative leap’ in the team’s design activity when John proposed that ‘maybe it’s like a little vacuum-formed tray’, and this tray concept became key to developing the team’s final design proposal. Did the tray idea just come ‘out of the blue’ or was it an ‘accumulation’ of previous ideas and contributions? It was certainly the first instance of the use of the word ‘tray’, but some possibly related concepts that had been mentioned earlier included references to plastic as a possible material and flat, solid forms for the rack device. In fact, nearly twenty minutes earlier than he first expressed the tray idea, John had referred to a similar kind of rack idea that he recalled: ‘Actually a friend of mine suggested, a couple of years ago, a product that he would do, an injection-moulded rack that would kind of like fold down.’ And Ivan immediately responded with recalling a similar bicycle luggage device that he remembered: ‘It’s like a little rack that was flat, it had these panels . . . but these panels were solid, it had little wheels . . . and it would come off and then it would be like a little trailer.’ Ivan went on to explain how it worked when folded up on the back of a bicycle by over-drawing it on a sketch that Kerry had made (silently) much earlier of something very like a ‘tray’ on the back of a bike (Figure 7.2).

So ideas related to the device as a tray-like, flat sheet, probably of plastic, had been suggested earlier, both explicitly by John and Ivan and implicitly by Kerry in her sketch. The significant difference seems to be the overt expression by John of this concept as a ‘tray’ – that is a flat surface with a raised lip around its circumference. The strength of the ‘tray’ concept seems to be that it identified and summarized an easily recognizable, appropriate solution form, in a way that was significantly different from the earlier concepts of a ‘flat’, ‘folded’, ‘panel’. We can see that it drew upon those earlier concepts that, in retrospect, seem very similar, but that lacked the apparently critical feature of ‘containment’ that a tray has. Its generation was perhaps aided by the immediately prior consideration of a more extreme form

of containment, a bag. Like the bag, the tray concept seemed to focus on one particular problem (containing the backpack’s straps) as the most significant consideration, but it was quickly elaborated to satisfy a range of other problems and functions. John’s expression of the concept was also timely – it came at the point when the team was trying to ‘select a concept’ and move on from problem exploration and concept generation to final design work.

It might seem that John’s apparently sudden expression of the ‘tray’ concept is an example of a ‘creative leap’. However, our analysis has shown that the expression of the concept actually ‘accumulates’ a lot of prior concepts, examples and discussions within the team. It is more like the key frame of ‘keep newspapers separate’ that occurred for the litter bin designers in Chapter 4. Creative designing is not necessarily the making of a sudden ‘leap’ from the problem space into the solution space, from requirements to solution, but is the formulation of an apposite proposal. Once the proposal is made, it is seen to be an apposite response to the given, explored and framed problem situation. It is an abductively reasoned conclusion that creates a resolution of the design requirements on the one hand and the design structure of a potential new product on the other, a matching problem-solution pair. The apparent sudden illumination that

HOW DESIGNERS WORK

can occur in creative designing is therefore more like constructing a ‘creative bridge’ between the problem space and the solution space than like taking a ‘creative leap’ from one to the other.

Summary

Designing is usually a social process of teamwork, with members playing different roles; a designer working alone has to internally play the different roles. The leadership influence of a member in a team arises from how they interact with the others, articulating shared understanding of the problem and accumulating and progressing solution idea concepts. A successful team’s discussion shows coherent development, with the team members building upon each other’s contributions. Process awareness is a cognitive creativity skill that facilitates progress. In initiating and coordinating the process, a team leader is performing acts of metacognition. A design team may set up a planned procedure, but they recognize that this is a framework that will be adapted as the work progresses. Externalizing aspects of the process, through the use of sticky notes, drawings and other modelling, are ways of opening up the design process and making social interaction cooperative and creative. When a key concept is voiced other members of the team recognize it as important and apposite, combining a resolution of the design requirements on the one hand and the structure of a potential design solution on the other: a proposal of a matching problem-solution pair. The apparent sudden illumination is more like constructing a creative bridge between the problem space and the solution space than like taking a creative leap from one to the other.

Design expertise

At the beginning of this book, in Chapter 1, I set out some of the

ways that the activity of designing can be investigated, and in the intervening chapters I have reported and discussed some of my own studies and related these to the work of other researchers. In the main, my approach has been one of empirical investigation, based on reported experience or observation and analysis. In explaining and relating these various studies, I have tried to build an evidence-based understanding of how designers think and work, and the nature of expert performance in design. In this final chapter I will consider design expertise more generally, its development from novice to expert, and suggest that the developed cognitive skills of design thinking can be regarded as a particular form of intelligence.

Experts and novices

Many of the classic studies of expertise have been based on examples of game-playing (such as chess) or on comparisons of experts versus novices in solving routine problems (e.g. in puzzle solving). These studies are generally examples of solving what are called well-defined problems, whereas designers characteristically deal with ill-defined problems, where there is no definitive, complete formulation of the problem and no single or verifiably correct solution. Some of the standard results from the classic studies of expertise do not match with results from studies of expertise in creative domains

156

DESIGN THINKING

such as design. For example, creative experts might reformulate the given task so that it is more problematic – that is deliberately treat it as ill-defined – which is contrary to the assumption that experts will generally solve a problem in the ‘easiest’ way or certainly with more ease than novices. In some ways, therefore, experts in creative fields treat problems as ‘harder’ problems than do novices. We saw examples of that in the discussion of design ability in Chapter 1 and in the case studies of Gordon Murray and Kenneth Grange: examples of designers going beyond the brief or ‘given’ problem.

Experts will often see a given problem as more complex than do novices, partly because of their greater experience. In studies of problem-solving, novice behaviour is usually associated with a ‘depth-first’ approach, which means that the novice identifies a problem aspect and immediately begins exploring its solution in depth. In designing, this results in partial sub-solutions that may be difficult to reconcile together into a satisfactory overall solution. The strategies of experts, however, are usually regarded as exhibiting predominantly breadth-first approaches, that is starting with a broad problem exploration and developing partial sub-solutions together in parallel. In designing, this is reflected in expert designers’ considering broader contextual aspects of the design problem before moving on to aspects of more detail.

Some depth-first and breadth-first aspects were observed between the behaviour of novice and experienced designers in studies by Saeema Ahmed and her colleagues. They found clear differences between the behaviours of new graduate entrants to the engineering profession and much more experienced design engineers. The novices used ‘trial and error’ techniques of generating and implementing a design modification, evaluating it, then generating another and so on through many iterations. Experienced engineers were observed to make a preliminary evaluation of their tentative decisions before implementing them and making a final evaluation. They used the foresight they had gained from experience to consider whether it seemed worthwhile to move further into the implementation stage of a design decision.

However, a more complex view has gradually emerged as more studies are made of expert designer behaviour. We have already seen how designers can exhibit opportunistic behaviour in pursuing

DESIGN EXPERTISE

interesting conjectures in more depth before returning to a broader strategy. This was contextualized further by Linden Ball and his colleagues, who studied the strategies of both hardware and software designers and suggested that ‘experts will often tend to mix both breadth-first and depth-first solution development strategies . . . the preferred strategy of expert designers is a top-down, breadth-first one, but experts will switch to depth-first design to deal strategically with situations where their knowledge is stretched. Thus, depth- first design is a response to factors such as problem complexity and design uncertainty.’ This suggests that, as well as spotting promising opportunities for solution generation, even expert designers will run up against unfamiliar problems and will have to make some initial in-depth exploration of partial solution concepts in order to assess their viability.

From novice to expert

We are all familiar with the concepts of the novice learner and the expert performer, and aware that something happens in the development from one to the other. A novice undergoes training and education in their chosen field and then at some later point becomes an expert.

The development of expertise usually seems to pass through different phases (Figure 8.1). In all fields, the accumulation of experience is a vital part of the transformation from novice to expert. For some people, the expert level of achievement is where they remain, perhaps with some continued moderate improvement before reaching their peak and beginning their decline. A few manage to go beyond the level of their peers into a further stage of development, reaching outstanding levels of achievement and mastery. At the other end of the scale of maturity, at a young age, all of us are introduced to a variety of human activities, whether it be making music, playing football, drawing pictures or writing stories. We all improve a little, but some, as noted earlier, will begin to practice with a dedication – and probably a joy or even obsession – that sets them apart.

158

DESIGN THINKING

FIGURE 8.1 Progressive stages in the development of expertise.

Moving from one level of expertise to another is not necessarily a steady progression. It is not simply a matter of knowing more and learning to work more quickly or smoothly. The changes in level involve learning to work in different ways. This shift to working in a different way can develop almost unnoticed by the learner but can mean shifts in level of attention that we all experience in learning a skill, as the fundamental practices become performed less consciously and flow more easily.

There has been much more of a history of studies on understanding expertise and expert performance in fields and contexts other than design, including chess, music, science and sports. From these studies, there is a general view that expertise can only be developed over time as a person matures. Usually, there comes a point when a peak of performance is reached and then a seemingly inevitable decline begins. This performance peak will be reached at different ages in different domains: for physical sports, it may be around the age of middle-twenties, whereas in cognitive activities it may not be until much later in life; in the sciences, people seem to produce their best work in their thirties, whilst in the arts it may be in their forties. Some outstanding individuals seem to defy the general pattern of development-peak-decline and continue producing great work well into later years.

A general aspect that seems agreed from studies of expertise is that it requires a minimum period of practice and sustained

DESIGN EXPERTISE

involvement before performance reaches a recognized expert level of achievement – at least ten years from first involvement. This is a matter not simply of experience or exposure to the field of endeavour but of dedicated application. One of the key factors in the acquisition of expertise is believed to be deliberate, sustained, guided practice.

The psychologist Anders Ericsson, who is an expert in the study of expertise, has suggested that ‘The attained level of performance of many types of experts, such as musicians, chess players and athletes, is closely related to their accumulated amount of deliberate practice’. Usually, a young person may display a certain aptitude or interest, and parents or teachers then encourage and guide their development. But without the dedicated application of the individual, levels of performance will remain modest. Again, according to Ericsson,

Superior expert performance is primarily acquired . . . Many thousands of hours of deliberate practice and training are necessary to reach the highest levels of performance . . . Most international masters emphasise the role of motivation, concentration, and the willingness to work hard on improving performance . . . The masters seem to consider inborn capacities and innate talent as relatively unimportant.

So in all fields it seems that the key to the development of expertise is practice, practice, practice.

Development of expertise

As we have seen, many studies of expert designers suggest that from initial scoping of the given problem they move on to early solution conjectures and use these conjectures as a way of exploring and defining the problem and solution together. This solution-focused nature of designing was first noted by Bryan Lawson in comparisons he made of the problem-solving behaviours of scientists and architects. Lawson set the same problem-solving exercise for students of science and architecture and found that senior students could be distinguished as adopting predominantly either problem-focused or solution-focused strategies. The science students attempted to

DESIGN THINKING

discover the underlying structure, or rules of the problem in order to solve it (problem-focused), whereas the architects made solution attempts and then sought to improve them (solution-focused). These differences were noticeable amongst senior students but not amongst first-years, so it appeared that the architects had learned their solution-focused strategy during their education as an effective strategy for resolving the kinds of problems that they had been set. They had learned to think like designers.

Education in design has long-established practices that are assumed to help the progression from novice to expert, although in general they are not based on evaluated evidence. There is still rather limited understanding of the differences between novice and expert performance in design, and how to help students move from one to the other, but there has been some progress.

For example, Henri Christiaans found, from protocol studies of industrial design students, that junior students did not seek a lot of information on the project they were given, and tended to ‘solve a simple problem’, being unaware of a lot of potential criteria, difficulties and possibilities. These are characteristics of a novice. Amongst senior students he found that they could be divided into two types. Although they all gathered more project information than junior students, for one type the activity of gathering information was too dominant, and sometimes just a substitute activity for actually moving on to design work. The more successful type, in terms of the quality of their solutions, gathered rather less information but considered it more carefully and gave the impression of consciously building up a broader view of the problem.

Very similar conclusions were reached by Cynthia Atman and her colleagues, who found from protocol studies of engineering students that, amongst first-year students ‘those who spent a large proportion of their time defining the problem did not produce quality designs’. As with the industrial design students, it seemed that the novice engineering students just solved simple interpretations of the problem or became stuck in problem definition and did not progress satisfactorily into further stages of the design process. However, amongst senior students Atman did find that attention to initial ‘problem scoping’ (i.e. ‘adequately setting up the problem before analysis begins’, including gathering a larger amount and wider

DESIGN EXPERTISE

range of problem-related information) did result in better designs. In general, developing greater expertise means developing a broader and more complex understanding of what has to be achieved, and this seems to be the case in design: more experience leads to more sophisticated problem scoping and defining.

Developing design thinking

Cynthia Atman has led a significant programme of studies into the nature of design expertise and its development through education. She and her colleagues focused on recording and assessing the design processes of engineering students, through a series of laboratory-type protocol studies of design projects in different years of study. They also made complementary studies of the processes of experienced professional designers working on the same projects as were set for the students. They recorded the sequences of different activities that were employed by the designer throughout a design process, from problem definition to idea generation, through modelling and evaluating proposals, to communication of a final design. For each designer, the pattern of activities was portrayed in standardized timeline plots of their individual design processes. These timeline plots help to visualize and convey the process of designing. Figure 8.2 shows example design process timeline plots for students and expert designers tackling a playground design project. Each entry along the horizontal left to right timeline indicates the designer’s focus of attention across the rows of different types of activity.

A significant difference that can be observed between the patterns of activities is that experienced designers, as they progress through a design project, transition back and forth across a broad range of activities throughout the whole process. There is a general overall progression from problem definition and gathering data to deciding on and communicating a final proposal, with the majority of the designer’s attention being given to modelling ideas for solutions, but their attention is also constant across all the different activities, with frequent switching between them. Atman called this a ‘cascade pattern’ that is typical of experienced designers. It shows a ‘cascade’ of the designer’s attention, generally from top-left to lower-right in the

Experience

What we have seen throughout this book is that designing is a form of skilled behaviour. It has also become clear that, as with other skills, successful behaviours are something that can be learned. The performance of a skilled practitioner, whether musician, footballer or designer, appears to flow seamlessly, adapting their performance to the circumstances without faltering; but the learning of any skill relies on controlled practice and the development of underlying technique. It is not simply a matter of possessing ‘talent’ but comes as the result of a dedicated application to and practice in a chosen field, and the accumulation of experience.

Peter Lloyd and Peter Scott found from protocol studies of architects and engineering designers that, for both, their approach appeared to be related to the amount and type of their previous experience. They found that more experienced designers used more of a conjecturing, solution-focused approach, more of what they called ‘generative’ (productive or abductive) reasoning, in contrast to the deductive reasoning employed more by less-experienced designers. They concluded that, in particular, ‘It is specific experience of the problem type that enables designers to adopt a conjectural approach to designing, that of framing or perceiving design problems in terms of relevant solutions’.

Clearly, part of the development of expertise lies in the accumulation of experience. Something that distinguishes experts from novices is that the experts have been exposed to a large number of examples of the problems and solutions that occur in their domain. It is a matter not just of copying from examples but of learning from them. A key competency of an expert is the mental ability to stand back from the specifics of the accumulated knowledge of precedents and form more abstract conceptualizations pertinent to their domain of expertise.

DESIGN EXPERTISE

Experts are believed to be able to store and access information in larger ‘chunks’ than novices and to recognize underlying principles, rather than focusing on the surface features of problems. This kind of behaviour classically occurs in chess playing, where chess masters are able to survey chess board positions and recognize patterns, and strategies for resolving them, whereas novices cannot see beyond the next one or two moves.

Bryan Lawson has drawn parallels between expertise in chess and design, and suggested that design masters also recognize patterns in problem situations and draw upon knowledge of precedents that they have abstracted into solution principles, or ‘schemata’ as Lawson calls them. A typical design schema for an architect might be a way of organizing internal space, such as around an atrium, or for an industrial designer might be grouping together different functional parts of a product. Lawson also suggested that, like chess masters, design masters have repertoires of ‘gambits’, or ways of proceeding, of entering into and opening up the problem situation. A typical gambit might be like that of Kenneth Grange (Chapter 3), starting a new project by ‘trying to sort out just the functionality, just the handling of it, and by-and-large out of that comes a direction’.

In order to develop skilled expertise it seems that a novice needs lots and lots of practice, guided by good teachers. The novice designer also needs exposure to good examples of expert work in the domain, and needs to learn to perceive and retain these examples in terms of their underlying schemata or organizing principles. Like learning a language, it is a matter of immersion and internalizing different levels of understanding and achievement.

Just as design problems are ‘ill-defined’, so expert designers appear to be ‘ill-behaved’ problem solvers. Rather than the conventional behaviours of solvers of well-defined problems, designers are solution-focused, not problem-focused. This change of focus appears to be a feature of design expertise that develops with education and experience in designing. In particular, experience in a specific type of design domain enables designers to move quickly to formulating a problem frame and proposing a solution conjecture. Successful, experienced designers are repeatedly found to be pro- active in problem framing, actively imposing a view of the problem and directing the search for solution conjectures.

To cope with the uncertainty of dealing with ill-defined problems, a designer has to have the self-confidence to define, redefine, challenge and change the problem as given, in collaboration with the clients and stakeholders and in the light of solutions that emerge in the very process of designing. People who prefer the certainty of structured, well-defined problems are unlikely to appreciate the delight of being a designer.

Design intelligence

What I have attempted to show throughout this book is that design ability is a multi-faceted skill. More than that, I have tried to show that there are particular, designerly ways of thinking and working that identify designing as equivalent with other highly regarded forms of cognitive skill. In fact, it seems possible to make a reasonable claim that design ability is a form of natural intelligence, one of the kind that the psychologist Howard Gardner identified. Gardner’s view is that there is not just one form of intelligence (as conventionally identified in forms of ‘intelligence tests’), but several, relatively autonomous human intellectual competencies, including linguistic, musical, mathematical, bodily and spatial intelligences. It seems reasonable that we might add design intelligence to those.

The understanding of design expertise suggests that a designer has a high level of intelligence used to plan, review, reflect on, adapt and, above all, create novel solutions. We have seen many aspects of this design intelligence in this book. For example, we have seen that good designers have a way of thinking that involves operating across different levels of detail in a project, from high-level systemic goals to low-level physical principles. Rather than solving merely ‘the problem as given’ they apply their intelligence to the wider context and suggest imaginative, apposite solutions that resolve conflicts and uncertainties. They have cognitive skills of problem framing, of gathering and structuring problem data and creating coherent patterns from the data that indicate ways of resolving the issues and suggest possible solution concepts. Design intelligence involves an intense, reflective interaction with models and representations of problems and solutions, and an ability to shift easily and rapidly

DESIGN EXPERTISE

between concrete representations and abstract thought, between doing and thinking. Good designers also apply constructive thinking not only in their individual work but also in collaboration in teamwork.

The designing brain

The nature of design intelligence becomes particularly and tragically highlighted in rare cases where it is impaired through neurological damage to the brain, such as through a stroke. One of these cases was reported by cognitive scientists Vinod Goel and Jordan Grafman, who studied an architect who had had a seizure, associated with a tumour in his right prefrontal cortex, a region at the front of the brain that is associated with high-level cognitive functions. Before his attack, this person had practised successfully as an architect but was unable to do so afterwards. In an experiment, Goel and Grafman compared his post-seizure design ability with that of a ‘control’ participant, another architect with similar education and design experience, on being given a relatively simple task of re-designing a laboratory space. The sequences of design sketches that the two architects produced are shown in Figures 8.6 and 8.7. Each began by making a survey drawing of the existing laboratory and its furniture. The healthy control participant then produced a coherent series of sketches, beginning with abstracted considerations of circulation and organization, then developing proposals and refining the preferred one. The neurological patient produced three separate, basic and incomplete proposals, finishing with a ‘final proposal’ that was still inadequate and incomplete.

The differences in the thinking processes of the two people become clear in graphs of the amount of time each devoted to different cognitive activities, as revealed by their ‘think aloud’ comments made during the experiments. These are shown in Figure 8.8. The control participant focused initially on problem structuring, with periodical returns to that throughout the process. He then moved on to preliminary design and to refinement and detailing. His graph clearly shows a complex but controlled pattern of activities, with overlap and rapid transitions between activities. In contrast, the neurologically damaged patient spent a huge amount of time on

Neurological studies of brain activity have identified specific areas of the brain as being active during design thinking. Katerina Alexiou and her colleagues conducted such a study using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) of the brains of volunteers who performed two similar tasks that were presented in different ways: one corresponding to a well-defined problem-solving task and the other corresponding to a typically ill-defined design task. The tasks were to plan a simple domestic room layout using a given set of

it was given as: Arrange the furniture so that: the room is functional – the room is comfortable – it has at least a bed, a wardrobe and a desk. The problem-solving version is constrained and a correct solution can be formulated; the designing version is open-ended and qualitative and can have many satisfactory solutions. The results indicated that designing and problem-solving each involve cognitive functions associated with distinct brain networks and that designing draws on a more extensive network of brain areas in the right prefrontal cortex. The prefrontal cortex is involved in complex cognitive behaviours including planning and decision making.

The two hemispheres of the brain, right and left, have different cognitive specialisms. The neural networks specific to designing appear to lie more within the right rather than the left hemisphere of the brain. Neuroscience studies tend to confirm that the right hemisphere is more specialized in spatial and constructional tasks, in aesthetic perception and emotions. The left hemisphere is more specialized in language abilities and verbal reasoning. Damage to the left hemisphere often results in the loss of some speech functions, whereas damage to the right hemisphere, as we have seen, can result, amongst other things, in the loss of design ability.

A view of design thinking as a form of intelligence does not necessarily mean that some people ‘have it’ and some people do not. Design ability is something that everyone has, to some extent, because it is embedded in our brains as a natural cognitive function. Although everyone can design, like other forms of intelligence and ability design intelligence may be possessed, or may be manifested in performance, at higher levels by some people than by others. And like other forms of intelligence and ability, design intelligence is not simply a given ‘talent’ or ‘gift’ but can be trained and developed. Otherwise, what would be the point of having design schools?

Summary

Results from studies of expertise in creative domains such as design do not always match with results from standard studies of expertise; expert designers exhibit different strategies from conventional problem-solving. The development of expertise happens over

173

174

DESIGN THINKING

time as a person learns and matures, and usually passes through different levels of attainment. Moving from one level to another is not necessarily a steady progression: the changes in level involve internalizing different ways of working. Developing greater expertise generally means developing a broader and more complex understanding of goals, which is related to the amount and type of previous experience. Typically, experienced designers traverse across a broad range of activities throughout the whole design process. Achieving skilled patterns of design behaviour can be assisted through education and guided practice. An expert designer can be regarded as having a high level of a particular design intelligence. As with other cognitive abilities, aspects of design cognition are located in specific areas of the brain and can be impaired through neurological damage to the brain.
